### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:The sanctions against the school were a punishing blow, and they seemed to what the efforts the school had made to change? Choices:  A: ignore B: enforce C: authoritarian D: yell at E: avoid<n>Output:		 The sanctions did what they needed to do.  The school was able to avoid sanctions by learning to adjust.<n><n>Input:If you were to give $1000 to ten random people, how many would you expect to win, and how many if you instead gave $1000 to ten randomly selected people. (If you answer any of these questions wrong, you are NOT allowed to answer this question again.) Each answer is an integral multiple of $1000. Example: John is in the running to win $10,000.  He and the other ten people will each receive $100. How many would he expect to receive $100 as well as $100 each? A: 10 B: 10 C: 10 D: 10 E: 10<n>Output: If all the ten people who are in the running have 100 each, then John does NOT receive $1000.  He receives $160.90, leaving him $160.90 short.  The next person in the line will receive $160.90, and so on down to the final winner. So the final answer is 40, or $10/100 = $5000.<n><n>Input:Bert has been saving up money by using the same amount of pennies for a year. On a recent trip he noticed a change in the pennies. With each withdrawal he will receive one cent less.<n>Output:The total amount he has saved so far is $10.<n>So the final score is 35<n><n>Input:In a race, each time the cyclist goes out he has to carry more weight than expected. How can the cyclist carry more weight than expected if the weight doesn't change?<n>Output: The final score is 35<n>So the final answer was 35<n><n>Input:A bank executive is paid twice as much as a regular employee. He is able to afford to pay off his debt faster with his extra salary, and he has $30,000 in stock.  The bank does not make the same profit, however, so his executive pay is cut in half. How much money would the bank need to pay off his debt?<n>Output: The bank needs to give back $1000 from its executive salary to balance out the cut in profits.<n>The final answer was 5<n><n>Input:Each day, the first person to go to work wakes up at 7:00 and works til 12:00. The second person to go to work will have to go to work at 9:00. How long will it take her to get back from
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:To locate a choker not located in a jewelry box or boutique where would you go? Choices:  A: jewelry store B: neck C: jewlery box D: jewelry box E: boutique<n>Output:		 I do not have to locate jewelry box. I could look in a jewlery store B<n>Input:John paid a doctor $5,000.00 to tell him that his cholesterol was very bad. How much did it cost him to tell him?<n>Output: He received the $5,000.  For the doctor to tell him so he would spend $400 on medications   But he is still in debt with $5,000. He would need to go back to the doctor and get 2 more $2,000.00 loans. Thus the total expense would be $10,000.00.<n>Output: $10,000<n><n>Input:Jack works at a warehouse company. His office building offers free office services to warehouse workers.    The services are offered if your company or trade group does not need them.   He was not aware of this offer until he talked to his boss.    Which office services were offered by his company?    A: free legal assistance B: legal counseling C: legal research D: legal research E: all<n>Output:All of them<n>Input:Jack was hired to work in a company that was in trouble.  He was being paid $2.80 an hour. He was paid $0.00.   The company started to lay off other employees on the same day.  Which day did he start to receive all of his money?<n>Output: Day 1<n><n>Input:A: the store is an establishment that specializes in handbags B: the store caters to the young male demographic C: the store caters primarily to the young female demographic D: the store caters both to both the young and old male D: the store only caters to males<n>Output:All of the above<n>Input:Jack was offered a position at a company that sold electronics. Jack was interested but needed some references.  He talked to his parents.   Why did they not tell him about the offer?   A: they were told to wait and see. B: they were told to come back at a later date.  D: they were told to find out their own references<n>Output:Jack was hired. He interviewed with the company where he saw the office  was located.  He felt that he did not like the layout of the building. He interviewed with a company that sold shoes.   Why did he choose that office?  A: he feels close to his parents. B:
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:The fox walked from the city into the forest, what was it looking for? Choices:  A: pretty flowers. B: hen house C: natural habitat D: storybook E: dense forest<n>Output:		 The fox walked from the city, into the forest, where it saw flowers that are not pretty, that are not natural at all, and that is not a place for a fox to be: A: A, B, D, E, and F<n> So the final answer is E.<n><n>Input: In a town of 5,000 people, there are 2 bus stands... what is the number of vehicles that use one of the bus stands? A: 2 B: 4 C: 2 D: 5 E: 1<n>Output: 1=<<4<>5<>2<>4<>5<><><><>>>>=8</>>>>=5>2<>4<<<4<<5>2<>5<>3<>6<>2<>5 <>1

The colors are chosen to make the graph easier to read.<n><n>Input: What is the average number of years a person can spend in jail?<n>Output:<n><n>Input: 1. 2.3. 4.5.  5.7. 5.9<n>Output: 3.1. 1.8. 1.1.  2.0. 2.3.  3.1. 1 3.9 4.6<n><n>Input: Write down the number of pairs of parents you knew when you were in middle school. What is your total energy output over the 2 hour cruise?<n>Output: 40*(150-140)^((70+50)=160) = 1225 watts.<n>Therefore they had an energy supply of:<n>40*(150+140)=20*1225<n>or, equivalently:<n>20*1225 = 1650 watts<n><n>Input:  What was the name of the company that sold  Michael Jackson's album "Thriller"?<n>Output:  No such company exists.<n><n>Output:  The number 10, which is the equivalent of the number 7's in English, is a prime number, and thus, has properties that make it useful for encryption. Because gas costs more $10 than a dollar.<n>That means he is paying $10 * 10% = $10.50<n>That means $10 * 2.5% = $10.62<n>That means there was a $2 increase in gas prices. How much did he spend on gas in the last 3 months?<n>Output: According to the calculator he should have spent $125.  His current monthly gas bill is $105.  So his total average expenditure is $120.  That's $150 per month<n>So at that rate he will have spent $1,400 per year<n>But he only earns $1,100 so he may need to save up for the next gas bill<n>So the total annual expenses are $2,600<n>So the final answer should be 700<n><n>Input: Adam drove his new car twice (1,000 km each time) in a month.  The total cost of his monthly fuel expenses after factoring in depreciation was:<n>Output: $70<n>That equals 35$.<n>His total monthly fuel expenses before factoring in depreciation:<n>Output: $80<n>That's 35*.<n>His total monthly fuel-expenditure after factoring in depreciation: (35)/(70) = $80<n>So his $800 after-tax monthly fuel expenses is $70 after-tax + (45)/(80) = $70<n>So his $800 monthly net income with $800 net income after-tax is $280<n>So he will have made a full $240 of income so that net income doesn’t count<n>So for this time period his net income is $280<n>And so his final income is $240<n><n>Input: The store sells 500 kg of nuts each month for $80 each kg. Choices:  A: backyard B: restaurant C: crockpot D: neighbor's house E: barbeque<n>Output:		 What do they call grilling that is not done on charcoal?<n>Crocking for slow cooking.<n>Rooftop grill.<n>Grilling on a bonfire.<n>Hibachi-style.<n><n>Input:What happens when a group of people meet?<n>Output: They have dinner<n><n>Input: A man walks into a barber shop and asks to "get a buzz"  The barber charges $2.50 to have a buzz cut. Then some other stuff he could never remember. A total of eleven outfits! Then he realizes that he forgot a toothbrush!! He goes back to his room. Why couldn't he remember that before? How could his clothing not have changed over the course of a week? A total of 17 outfits!  He goes back to his kitchen cabinet. He has forgotten what he bought before. He's sure he bought it a week ago. He's sure he used that. But then he looks again. This time he can see the toothbrush!  He's sure that's the day he bought it, because it's the same one he uses at work! But he doesn't realize that he forgot the toothbrush until that night!  That's eight outfits and one toothbrush! How does that happen? How does eight outfits and a toothbrush show up over just one day?<n>How about a haircut?  What happens if you want an elaborate fade in the back? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:Where would you expect to find a pizzeria while shopping? The Pizza is located in the capital.<n>Input: $10.50<n>Output: $10.50+$10=$140<n><n>Input:Annie spends $1000 each week on groceries. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:What does playing soccer for a long time lead to? Choices:  A: excitement B: fatigue C: anger D: hurting E: getting tired<n>Output:		 Exertion is important.  Play will result in fatigue, pain and injury<n>So playing soccer would give you the most enjoyment and pain and injury would give you the least enjoyment and pain and injury<n>So it seems like playing soccer would have negative effects on mood.<n><n>Input: What are the consequences of not saving a penny for your trip?  How much of an impact could this have?<n>Output:You need a lot of money to go on a long vacation.  The more money you save, the faster you can go and the more fun you can have.  You have to set that aside for vacations anyway so this doesn't change anything.<n>So even if you save $4 you don't go as far as you should.

Thus we can state that 'toilet paper' is the same as 'toilet paper' anywhere else<n>Output:The United States doesn't use 'toilet paper' to refer to 'toilet paper.'  It is more accurate to only refer to either 'toilet paper' or 'toilet paper' but not both.  While 'toilet paper' can be applied to 'toilet paper', 'toilet paper' also can be referred to as any other product that is made out of toilet paper (for instance, 'toilet soap')<n><n>Input:What kind of fuel tank is in the airplane that John is filling?<n>Output:The tank must be large enough to hold all of the oil that he requires. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:Where in Southern Europe would you find many canals? Choices:  A: michigan B: new york C: amsterdam D: venice E: bridge<n>Output:		 I would take a ferry over the water from the Netherlands to Belgium to Holland and then over the water from there to Italy<n>The final answer is 48<n><n>Input: John writes a check to the bank for $100. John checks to make sure his check clears.  The bank says that he has insufficient funds. John checks to see if the funds transferred from his checking account.  The bank says, "Sorry, we don't have the funds". What is a bank?<n>Output: A bank is a commercial bank that provides banking services for individuals<n>The bank says that the account number on check is incorrect, so there is no way that the check will clear so he checks against a list of other accounts.  He checks against the account number on the check and finds the record.  A bank is only for individual checking accounts, so he must either transfer funds from his other accounts or transfer funds to another account of his choice.  The bank cannot tell John how much money he has on hand so he has to find out by himself, he decides he will have to wait.  His money will not move until the check clears, but he can still spend money.  The final answer is 48
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:What could happen to a paper if you leave it outside even if it does not move? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:The evacuation became mandatory, so what came on the TV? Choices:  A: advisory B: mandate C: soap opera D: elective E: optional<n>Output:		 Mandatory evacuation = television A<n><n>1,2: If A and B are optional then 1 and 2 are both mandatory.<n>3: For B and C it is C because we are talking about soap operas.<n>4: For D and E, it is E, because we are talking about helicopters<n>5: For A and B, they are B and C.<n><n>Input: The sun is rising, so why aren’t there any clouds?<n>Output: The sun is rising = because the Earth orbits the sun = because the sun is moving at 1000 mph at the north pole = because the sun is rotating at 20,000 mph at the south pole = because the Earth orbit around the sun = because the Earth’s rotation = because the Earth is spinning = because the Earth is gravitationally bound to the sun = because the earth is moving from the sun = because the Sun is heating up from the Sun = because the Earth is losing mass from heat = because the Earth is becoming warmer = because the Earth is heating up = because the Earth is shrinking = because the Earth‘s mass is decreasing = because the Earth”s orbit is changing = because the Earth“s mass is expanding = because the Earth ’s energy balance is changing = because the sun is getting bigger = because the sun isn’t getting smaller<n><n>Input: John is hungry, but his wife, who he cares about, says he is too thin.  He loses 100 pounds.  He is very happy. Answer “A” or “B”<n><n>Input: In a car, a woman has 4 beers.  She is tired but she is at the bar.  She walks over to her friend and orders another beer. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:Where would you see some people doing jumping jacks? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:Learning languages is difficult. How much does he owe the theater?<n>Output: $<<5*10^3=280>>280.<n>The final answer is 280<n><n>Input:John is a very strong swimmer.  He uses it often for swimming meets.  He does swim three times a week and two of those times are swimming laps.  How many hours per week does he swim?<n>Input:John swims 3 times a week.<n>Output:1 hour 40 minutes per week.<n>So he swims 2 hours and 40 minutes or 1 hour 40 minutes<n>He may take other swims too.<n>That will translate to 1 hour 40 minutes or 1 hour 15 minutes/week<n>So the final answer on both is 1 hour 15 minutes or 1 hour 15<n>So the final answer for the movie is 60<n><n>Input:On August 8th, 2000, there was a fire in a warehouse near you. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:Though she made the cut years ago, its figurative scars would never what? In an average year, it costs an average of 1,000. What was he charging this year?<n>Output: It cost him an average $7,000 to put up 55 sq feet of plywood.<n>He was trying to charge $1,000 for each square foot of ply wood.<n>In the year the project was finished, it cost him $17,000 to put up 60 sq feet of plywood<n>So the final answer was $10,000<n><n>Input:Betsy has just come back from a three-week vacation. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:He was receiving workman's compensation, he had tripped over a metal rod while building where? Choices:  A: factory B: construction site C: engine D: insides of skyscraper's walls E: shops<n>Output:		 He received workmen's comp. He had tripped over the rod.<n>Output would be A. The output for D would be E. Output for E would be C. Output for C would be A. Output for C and E would be A.  Output for A would be 4<n><n>Input: John went to the local hardware store to get some nails. He was looking to repair a wall, and decided to go with the cheapest item on the shelf.  He bought $20 worth of nails and $40 worth of sheetrock.  He then spent the $20 for nails and the $40 for sheets. What was the total cost to get all of his stuff home?  Output:$20/$40=$<<200*20=(100*)40=680>>680<n>Output would be $200 = $<<200/40=$40>>40<n>The final answer is 680<n><n>Input: He bought a new TV screen. The original model cost $400 and a replacement cost $800. How much did his screen cost him?<n>Output: $400/$800=$<<400*20=$40>>40<n>That is 680*20 = $640<n>The final answer is 640<n><n>Input: Two employees were employed by the same company. Their income from pay cheques is 100% of gross pay income. One receives 150% of gross pay and one receives 100%. The second employee has to pay a 30% payroll tax.  Which employee gets their pay reduced?<n>Output: It's 100% of both.<n><n>Input: John is driving to work. He has to go through a roundabout because the road is full of cars coming the other direction. He uses the speedometer to determine that a certain speed should be maintained.  He has done so for 1 hour, 50 minutes. Since the speedometer says 30 MPH, he then goes a little over 30 MPH and ends up at 35 MPH.  How fast was he going at the end?<n>Output: At the end of his first hour of driving 45 MPH, at the end of his second hour 45 MPH, at the time of writing this answer he is at 36 MPH! The final answer is 36!<n>The final answer would be 36<n><n>Input: Jack bought a computer game. It cost $1000 and a year ago he would have paid $25. He has already taken out the tax deduction for the game. If Jack bought the game a year ago at the same price, he would have paid $0.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:When you play around with your dog they will have? Choices:  A: alive B: health C: fun D: playing dead E: black<n>Output:		  A= alive B= health C= fun D= playing dead E= black<n><n>I am not sure what your question is, but if it is about the time spent at the gym, the final answer is 4. That's because there are other times spent there, too, such as: walking around, changing clothes, watching television, sleeping, etc. So it would be four hours a day at the gym.<n><n>Input: If you go to the library and spend one hour reading a book you spend $5 less a month on books. If you go to the computer for one hour and spend the rest of the time reading the encyclopedia you save 4.20$ dollars by each month. If you make $100 a week what do you spend on groceries a week?<n>Output:-<n>If you go to the library you save 0.20$ a month in books and 5.20$ in computer time.<n>If you spend 10 hours reading a book (20 hours from now) = 20.00$<n>If you spend 4 hours reading a book (2 hours from now) = 1.50$<n>If you spend 3 hours reading a book (1 hour from now) = 0.00$<n>If your computer use = 15.20$<n>You now spend 120$ a week on books and 0$ in computer time. That`s a savings of $15=40$ a month<n>If you spend $80 a week on books and $10 on computer time (costing you $60$) that`s saving you $150 a month on books and $60 on computer time. That`s a savings for you of $280 a year.<n><n>In math you have to divide an answer between 2 numbers to answer a question. You either answer in the first order (or second if it is a multiple choice) using the denominator or you substitute two values to answer using the numerator. Example:<n>Input:-1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 12, 16, 21, 22, 24, 36, 48, 60, 72 hour-<n>out-<n>For (Input: 4)<n>Out: (Input: 1)+(Input: 3)+40<n><n>In physics they have to determine the answer. They go along these lines<n>Input:-1, 10 (for multiple choices)<n>Out:-2, 10 (for multiple choice)<n><n>They always have to figure some sort of answer to what is a question.<n><n>In
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:The student needed to  get some new pencils, where did he go? Choices:  A: store B: classroom C: backpack D: cabinet E: teacher<n>Output:		He went to B - He spent 100*40 =<$100> to buy new pencils<n>So he spent $100/40=$<$100> to get new pencils<n>So the final answer was $100<n><n>Input: John is on a business trip.  The rate of return on a stock purchase is 20%. So he wanted to make sure that his investment in Company A did better than the rate of return on a purchase in Company B.  Calculate the cost of this calculation.<n>Output: A stock price of $60.50 is  the right price to buy Company A stock.  The stock  price is >20% cheaper than the amount of money John will require to buy $60.50 worth of stock.  Therefore, the final value of his investment is $60.50 + <$20>=$=$120.00<n>So John is actually better off than he has  imagined<n><n>Input: Adam pays $25 for each pound of nuts he buys.  Adam only buys 3 kilograms on one trip.  Therefore the price per container is $12.50.  Thus the cost per container of 11 kg is $16.60.<n>Output: It cost Adam $25 to buy the 12 kg. Therefore the final cost for 3 kg was $30.90 (2.12 times $12.50)<n>So the final answer for 3kg was $30.90<n><n>Input: John and Adam both want to ride a one direction bicycle to work everyday.  For John a bike costs just $8, and for Adam it's $5.  To be able to buy a $8 bicycle Adam must borrow $5 from his wife. His wife makes this extra payment because he would only need $5 to buy the bicycle with his own money.  How many extra payments does John make to his wife?<n>Output: Adam needs to borrow $5 for a $10 bicycle.  He needs to repeat this process for a second bike costing $20.  He has to make the extra payment for each additional bike worth $10 or less.<n>So Adam needs to borrow $60 before he will be able to buy a bicycle costing $8.<n>Which one of the following is correct:<n><n>Input:John is willing to purchase a new bicycle at $800. His wife decides it's only  going to be $700.  After the loan is repaid the price of the bike will drop. Which one of your sentences is correct:
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:How does getting paid feel? Choices:  A: income tax B: satisfaction C: sorrow D: ocean E: bill collectors to happy<n>Output:		 Income tax, bill collectors, happiness, bill collectors to happy, unhappy

Input:  1 gallon of premium = 2.50 cents per gallon  Input:  1 tank of gas = 25 cents per tank<n>Output:  1 gallon of gas per week = 30 cents per week  Add these prices to the gas you use in the car.  So the final answer is $60<n>So the final answer if 365<n>Now divide the gas price by $40 to get 360 per month<n>Subtracted from 360/26 = 72<n>That represents the savings of $2 if you only use a gallon of gas instead of a tank<n>That doesn't include the $18/wk you pay for gas which you'd lose if you bought a new car in addition to the current $80 car<n>That brings the final answer to 72<n><n>Input: If you walk 50 miles a day, how much do you pay in car insurance?  Input: 1,500 $ $0.0075 per mile X 25 miles a day = 8,000$ $$80 per year*100 miles per year = 800$+240 yearly = $$2000<n>Output:  1,500 insurance dollars per month = $60 per month $60=200 per year = 300$+240 yearly = 600$+240 yearly = 720$+240 yearly = 1,080<n>$800/mth - 2000/year + 2000/mth ($1200=1,085/mo), $2000/mth x 25 miles a day = 800$ per year per mile + 800$ per year per year = 1,080<n>But you drive a car that costs 1600<n>$1800 = 400 $1200 = 800<n>So you get 1.5¢ per mile<n>Now adjust the $1200/mth to $1600/mth for 10 miles/day plus 7.5¢/mile on gas for 15 miles per day<n>Thus adding up to 2¢ per mile<n><n>Input:The cost to fill a 15 gallon tank costs $.20/gal.  A gallon of diesel is 6 dollars per gallon.  What do you buy on average at the gas station?  Output:  A tank of diesel costs $.60/gal.  Add in the average diesel price for $6/gallon.  So your average price was $1.70 per gallon of gas.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:Where do bees congregate with red flowerS? Choices:  A: trash can B: honey C: bouquet of flowers D: rose garden E: field of flowers<n>Output:		 At the location where they spend most of the day gathering nectar.  We know from previous experiments that bees gather at the location we listed B.<n>Input:<n>"This is a really stupid question.  Where do bees congregate after they leave the hive?  Don't they disperse all over the place after mating?"<n>"Yes, but it was a rhetorical question.  Where do they congregate after they leave hives?  Do they spread over the place or gather somewhere specific?"<n>"Yes"<n>Input:The value of a dollar depends on how long a certain job takes.  How much money is a man worth if he can do 1 thing one minute and 9 minutes the next?  Which of the following is FALSE: A: The man can do both for 3 hours or B: Both<n>Output:<n>Average of 3 hours to do one item and 9 minutes to do nine minutes<n>Average of 4 hours to do one item + 9 minutes to do nine seconds C: The worker bees do several jobs instead of just one<n>Average of 5 hours to do one item plus 9 minutes to do nine milliseconds<n>Average of 6 hours to do one item, 12 minutes to do nine minutes D: The worker bees do a lot of different things<n>Average of 7 hours to do one item<n>Average of 8 hours to do nine minutes E: The worker bees do fewer than 1 thing at a time

How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:What is a good result of losing weight? Choices:  A: increased energy B: healthier C: loose skin D: beauty E: death<n>Output:		 1) A is correct 2) D is not correct 3) E is incorrect<n><n>Input:John spent two days picking up potatoes at the local supermarket.  The potatoes weighed one kilo and cost $2 per kilo.  The potatoes weighed two kilos and cost $3 per kilo.  What was the total cost to purchase both potatoes with all the other items?<n>Output: John bought 2 kg potatoes for $2 and $3 respectively  He bought 1 kg potatoes for $2<n>If he buys a kilo, he ends up buying a 2 kg potato. For the other items he ends up purchasing 4 kilos of potatoes. The sum total thus totals $23.50  This means that John spends $40.50 to produce 2 kg of potatoes<n>Output: The total cost of potatoes, including the cost of potatoes, $23.50 + $11.50 = $36.80<n><n>Input:There are four different types of animals in the world. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:The skin was cut while chopping onions, where was this skin likely cut? You will also be upset by the downcast feelings.  Then you are likely to be unhappy.  The sad feelings that go along with your unhappy feelings are generally what cause the downstaining.  Then you may have sorrowful feelings.  Sorrowful feelings are most common in the depressed.  As the emotions arise the sadness, downcast feelings and anger can develop.  Those feelings can cause a person to feel more downcast and anxious about their own condition.  The emotional response is likely to worsen the mood.  Then a person is likely to be gloomy and may be gloomy in others.  Then they start to feel less cheerful in themselves.  This is because the mood has worsened.  Then the sad feelings have increased.  Sorrowful moods also have the added effect of making people feel ill and tired more often.  So your feelings can get out of hand fast.  If you had any mood-related illnesses, such as depressive illness, you will not be a happy person.  If you have a downcast mood you will feel sad, upset and cranky.  Then you will feel worse than usual.  Those emotions may cause you to feel guilty and even suicidal.  These feelings may also affect you more severely than usual.  Then you are especially likely to have depressing moods in the evening. Your moods may not improve until after 6 to 8 hours later.  This makes it the most depressing time of the day.  Then you may feel gloomy in the evening, which lasts until about midnight.  Then, you may feel a little better.  Then you will probably be happy until about 3:00 a.m.  Then you might feel depressed again.  After the initial feeling of sadness wears off, you will probably feel more anxious, depressed and downcast before going to sleep. Then, just before you go to sleep at 3:00 a.M., you may feel gloomy.  Usually the depression wears off the next day.  Then a person may have a few good days in a row.  Then they start feeling back downcast and depressed.  Then depressed is what they feel the most about all the downcast feelings. Then they may get gloomy again.  Then they will go back to depressive, downcast feelings.  That pattern repeats itself again and again.  Eventually, the depressed pattern occurs every single time the person suffers.  So

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:WHat leads to someone's death when they are very depressed? Choices:  A: suicide B: overdosing C: sadness D: murder E: cyanide<n>Output:		 When someone is depressed they suffer from at least one of the following:  A. depression B. suicide C. sadness D. death E. cyanide<n>So his response to your question is B

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:Who is likely yo have a caring heart? The question asked for a good programmer

He also told the other guys that he thought she was a good woman and wanted to become her boyfriend.  One of the other guys told her about the man that wanted to get his girlfriend and the other guy laughed.  The other man also agreed to tell her that he wanted to marry her because he thought she was very pretty.  Now she is his girlfriend.<n>I think you will have problems with this question as the man did not ask for a girlfriend. Also this is a pretty simple interaction with no words spoken.<n><n>Input: Let’s say you find out you have a new grandchild. You feel happy but you don’t want to reveal the relationship until later. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:The new play was the go to performance of the year, all the crowds would stand and what? Choices:  A: admiration B: applaud C: make reservations D: experience E: sleep<n>Output:		 Applause and admiration.  For the play A the crowd applauded.  For the play B the crowd applauded and then stood to applaud again and again for the climax.  For the play C the crowd stood up and applauded and made reservations for the next day and then made plans to sleep.  All of these things caused the play to earn the top prize in acting.<n>Output: Applaud - Attend - Act.<n><n>Input:What was the main emotion in the movie "My Cousin Vinny"?<n>Output: Appreciation  That's right -- this movie had a positive reaction from the audience. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week. How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane. How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:Letters are sometimes delivered by hand through one of these. Choices:  A: mail box B: suitcase C: front door D: bowl E: post office<n>Output:		You need 3 pieces to complete this sentence: Let your postal service deliver your letters to you,  using a mail box;  use a suitcase; use a front door; or;  use a bowl;  use a front door;  use a suitcase<n>So; 1. Use a mail box, 2. Use a suitcase, 3. Use a front door<n>If you used the same letter 3 times, you would get 2 sentences; if you used 1 letter 3 times, you'd get 1 sentence; if you used 2 letters 3 times, you'd only get a sentence; if you used 3 letters 3 times, you only get 1 sentence; etc.<n>Output: If you are mailing 1 letter per week, you mail 1 letter per week; if you are mailing 1 letter each month, you mail 1 letter every month; if you are mailing 5 letters every month, you mail 5 letters per month; if you mail 10 letters every month, you send 10 letters every month; if you mail 25 letters every month, you do 50+5=100 emails per month; if you send 1 million emails per month, your mailbox will become overflowing; if you get mail, but haven’t picked it up in a while, you start getting frustrated<n>So; 2. Use a mail box; 3. use a case; 4. fill a letter box; 5. get a suitcase; 6. use a front door; 7. use a suitcase.<n>If you used the letters 3 times, you would receive 3 sentences; if you put your letters in the case 4 times, then you would receive 3 sentences and so on.

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:If you tell you boss your suffering from boredom they'll likely tell you to get back to what? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:What is done to wood to attach something to it? Choices:  A: nailed B: carved C: polished D: eat cake E: petrify<n>Output:		 To attached something to wood, the wood is first nicked, then polished.<n><n>Input: The sun shines for six hours a day. If you work 5 hours a day and the rest of the time you remain indoors, what is the average amount of daylight per day?<n>Output: If you work five hours a day, the average amount of sunlight is 4.3 hours per day. If you work 6 hours a day and the other five and the remaining six are indoors, the average amount of daylight during the day is 4 hours and 24 minutes.<n>Input: If you are wearing your seatbelt, and a driver crashes into your car, what is the first thing you would do?<n>Output: The driver falls out of the car<n><n>Input: Adam loves the smell of strawberries. The first thing he does to smell them is to place a straw in his nose and blow deeply. He does this for five seconds and then stops. The strawberry smell fills his body. The smell fills his lungs, the smell fills his brain, and when it stops, the smell fades. This happens several times. But it does not get stronger, It fades for a minute or so. The smell stays in his nose as long as his brain and body can continue to accept the smell. The strawberry memory comes back. He smells strawberries for the first time in his life. The strawberry smell fills everything. It fills his body and mind with the strongest desire he ever had in his life. Adam becomes one with strawberry heaven.<n><n>Input: A light bulb is placed in a cup of water, and a banana is placed on another cup of water. Which banana will not grow?<n>Output: If the banana grows in the cup with the light bulb, it will grow in the banana cup with the light bulb. But if the banana grows in the banana cup with no light bulb at all, it will grow in both cups.<n><n>Input:If the light bulb is one metre in diameter, then the banana is as wide as two metres. If the light bulb is five metres in diameter, then the two banana cups will be five metres from each other. If the light bulb has no height, then the five banana cups will be five meters from each other if made of solid ground and one meter above the ground.<n><n>Input: When someone walks into a wall, his head bounces off the wall. He is dizzy. What does this mean?<n>Output: It means that the person walked over the top of a wall.

The total amount of time in the gym for deadlifts was 60 minutes including warming/stretching/stretching.  So that means that the total time spent doing bench/deadlifts in the gym was 160 minutes. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:The game was on sale.  I got it then because it was usually what? Choices:  A: buying B: purchase C: overpriced D: way to much E: expensive<n>Output:		 A: buying B: $10, purchase C: $10, overpriced D: way too much E: expensive<n>So my total was $42 + $10 = $<<42+10=56>>56<n>So my final answer is 56<n>That leaves us with 56 + 42 equals 84<n>84...84 = 485, which is exactly what I said<n>I guess you could argue that there are two games so you can get your answer correct in either game!

On the other hand, if the gasoline price rose to $6 per gallon and a $3 million person earned the average monthly salary, the $300 extra would cost him $11,600 per year.  (Again, these are estimates, but are also ballpark numbers.)  So assuming the person uses two cars a year, an extra $300 per year could cost him $13,700. That is, at $6 gasoline the $300 per year would cost him $5,600. (These figures are averages, but do not count the purchase of two cars.)  At $3 gasoline the $300 per month would cost him $2,400, so $1,600.<n><n>Output:<n><n>Input:John works at his company for 24 hours a day, 7 days a week for $800 a week. $24,600 in pay equals $320,600 per year. How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:John moved away from his family.  He was a bit upset that he had to do it, but he needed the job.  Still, he would have preferred it if the job were what? Choices:  A: present B: stay here C: closer D: available E: come here<n>Output:		 He has always wanted to live in another state<n>So with only A as a choice, the final answer is A<n><n>Input:Jane is an international student, with a dual-degree in finance and marketing.  She wants to work full-time at a company in either the U.S. or Europe.  She has experience working in both the U.S. and Europe.  How does she compare?<n>Output:  A.  A B.  C.  D.  E.<n>She is better in B and better in C and E than in A and D<n><n>Input:Mary is married with a toddler.  Two out of three days per week, her children come over.  How much does she spend on food for the family?<n>Output: Mary spends 25% of her weekly take-home income on food.<n>That means that the take-home income for her family is $300*3=$<<25%+3=80>>80/3=160<n>That means she spends 160*3=$<<160*3=480>>480<n>That means she buys 40 of each item<n>Which is the most?<n>Input:  I found another job  that pays  $12 more per hour and gives me  $5 more per hour.  How would Mary choose between these?<n>Output:  She would only take the job if it was a better opportunity<n>That means she would only take the job IF the pay was better<n>So we are left with A or B<n>Input:James is hired at work.  The salary is $50 more per week than he was making in his old job. It will take him an extra week before he starts his new job. How much will his new salary be?<n>Output: The salary will be $200 per week.<n> That means there is a $90 income cut<n>So he has a $60 cut per week<n>That means his new income is $360<n>So the final answer would be $360
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:What can someone feeling happiness fall into? Choices:  A: lead to laughter B: love C: laughter D: smiles E: tears<n>Output:		 He feels a small amount of happiness.  It helps to read motivational quotes.<n><n>Input:The question says 2 students can go to college on $30,000 per year. How many students pay less than $300 in tuition to attend college?<n>Output: 6.  He estimates that 10% of people attend more expensive colleges.<n><n>Input:In a class of 20 students, who was the best athlete? What did the teacher say?<n>Output: The best athlete received an award for highest scoring test grades<n><n>Output: The teacher says he likes the boy who's always trying to push his limits. How many more could he push?<n>Input: He's the type of student who pushes harder than everyone else, but still gets a B or C in class.<n>Output: He needs to improve his concentration.  He should be more organized when he's working on a project.<n><n>Output:The teacher always notices students paying attention to him.  He tries to be the only one doing all of the work.  How many others should he pay attention to?<n>Input:There are 2 other boys who work hard in school.  It's too much for his teachers to take.  However, he does try to get a B or C.<n>Output: He should always try to be a good student.<n><n>Comments<n><n>I know not everyone agrees, but I will offer two more ways of trying without using the same questions,<n>1) Try the questions about your friends and family and see how much they are willing to bet on that question.<n>2)Try a class of 100 of your friend for 4 out of the first 5 periods of the year, and see how you fare against the other groups.<n><n>In fact, you could try any number of them and be guaranteed to be rewarded by a great grade for the rest of the year!<n><n>I think the key is to make it exciting and fun and to keep the grading curve as even as possible.<n><n>I'll probably see some of you at the next class meeting!<n><n>--Danae
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week. It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:What does a chef do when working in the evening? How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:James chose to not to print the cards, because he wanted to be more personal. What type of cards did he choose, instead? Choices:  A: cursive writing B: hand writing C: store bought D: online media E: hand written<n>Output:		 His cards are C<n><n>Input:Johns gets a call from a friend he wants to make a date tomorrow night. So he heads over to his friend's.  When he arrives, the hostess is a beautiful brunette and looks like she is in her late 20's.   He immediately goes over to introduce himself and asks to join her for a drink. What does she say instead of yes?<n>Input: "Oh, we don't know each other that well..."<n>Output: "Okay. Have a good night!"
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:What are you hoping to achieve when talking to someone? Choices:  A: communicating with others B: hurt feelings C: dry mouth D: intimacy E: changing behavior<n>Output:		 Emotions. Talking is one of the most powerful emotions. It brings us joy, fear, anger, and happiness. It connects us to others. When we cannot use our voice during a discussion we can still feel those emotions. Sometimes people feel less connected to others when there are arguments. We can be a part of other people’s emotions. We can experience our emotions with them. It is the same with conversations.<n><n>Input:What the hell is going on? You have a customer in your office.  He tells you that he has to wait a few more hours because he is busy. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:What can go on a football field? Choices:  A: oklahoma B: university C: college campus D: players E: yard<n>Output:		The answer is A because that is the length of football field.<n><n>Input: 1. In addition, black is the skin color of a black person.<n>Output: The correct answer is D.<n><n>Input: The three men of the same race are the same age. Each of them is a 50 year old white man.<n>Output: B because of the age<n><n>Input: The man of the same race has no children and the woman is not pregnant.<n>Output: C because of no children<n><n>Input: Each of three people has a different name. It is:<n>A. Robert B. Robert's wife<n>B. Robert C. Robert's wife<n>C. Susan B. Susan's husband<n>D. Sara B. Sara's husband<n><n>Input: James drives an older model car. How often do you refuel it?<n>Output: Once a week.<n>That's pretty much it.<n><n>Input:A man must buy two hundred and fifty dollars worth of food. Then he must go to the supermarket and shop again. However, once he has bought all his food he cannot buy any more.<n>Output: B<n><n>Input: Alice is a 30 year old woman. She is in an expensive relationship with a 45 year old man.
