### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:If your watching television and accomplish nothing what have you done? Choices:  A: getting fat B: get fat C: typing words D: falling asleep E: wasted time<n>Output:		Watching television for 40 minutes costs $2 A/40=$<<$2/40=$<<$2/40=$40>>40<n>So watching television for two hours costs $2 plus 20/40=$<<$3/40=$40>>20<n>So two hours now costs $3*40=$60 A/40=$<<($3/40=$60)>>60<n>So two hours now is $3*60+60=$<<60+60=240$10<n>So three hours now is $10*40=$120 A/40=$<<60*40=$120>>40<n>So three hours now = $120*40=$160 A/40=$>120<n>So three hours now equals $160<n>So the final answer for the following question is 160<n><n>Input: A doctor tells a man that he has a heart problem and to undergo three operations within the next five years. The surgery that takes place is successful and the heart is restored to health. After five years the doctor is sure to tell the man that his health has been excellent.  The man has a new house built with a pool. He has a son who is only about fifteen years old. He has met and married his wife who makes several trips to Paris and other parts of Europe. When his wife goes to work her son does not eat vegetables.  How much will the man spend on house repairs in five years?<n>Output: The total cost of house repairs will be $160 * 20 = $160,000<n>So the total repair costs in five years will be $160,000<n>Since he bought a new house and made several trips he will spend $80,000 on new house repairs<n>So his total cost of repairs in five years will be 160<n>So the final answer to the following question is 160

On those days she has to write $200 out of her pay check and hand it over to the banker.  The banker will then write back $200 and issue her a check for it.<n>Output: Jane has to deposit $200 twice ($200 * $200 = 1000$) at the banks. She has to deposit another $200 every time she sends out a paycheck.  She has to use the check to make the deposit.  She has to write $200 from the check into her personal and business banking accounts.  She has to make a decision as to whether to spend extra money to pay for herself and make a check deposit or not.<n>So the final output would be $200 * $200=$1200$1050<n>So you would expect that at least one payment would be returned per day.  Therefore, it would cost $1200*60 = $1200 to make a deposit.  If the banker keeps $1 in his business account, he has $60 left over at the end of the day.  If the banker has $60 in his personal account, he has $600 left over at the end.  So the $1200 is worth more than $60.  In summary, the banker keeps $600 of all the money he has, so it is not as if the banker is loosing much money by keeping $1.  Therefore, the banker does not have to keep $1 per check. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:Where would you sit in a chair to watch four-legged animals complete? Choices:  A: bookstore B: house C: race track D: friend's house E: building<n>Output:		 At a bookstore.  For a single story building the space would be less than 250*4=1200>1,100>1,500>1,800>1130<n>So the final answer for the three buildings is 1210>1130>1,100.<n>>1,100>1130>1.500>1,800>(1,066>1170)>>1170<n>So the final answer here is 1170<n><n>Input:James is driving for a large company in a car that has 50,000 miles on it.  Every other week the fuel cell needs to be replaced.  What does he have to replace?Output: A pack of chewing gum, 3 bottles of water, 10 ice cream coupons and 1 dollar bill<n>He has 70 bucks left so he will be able to replace the pack of gum and two ice cream coupons<n>So now he has $85 left and he still has to buy the dollar bill<n>So the final answer will be 85$/70=$<<85/70=45>>45<n>So to replace just a gum pack he needed 47$<n>(47-70=$<<47/70=15>>15)<n>So just a pack of gum was 11.8$ to replace<n><n>Input:Who is a better model for the stock market? The Dow Jones Stock Exchange or Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index?  Answers:<n>The Dow Jones Stock Exchange- for small and large companies and the S&P 500- for individual stocks<n>Output: The Dow Jones Stock Exchange- the smaller companies and the S& P 500- the large companies<n>So the final answer as mentioned above is the Dow Jones Stock Exchange<n><n>Input:Diet soda costs 5 cents per ounce. An 8 ounce bottle costs $1.10. Soda contains 1½ teaspoons of sugar, 2 teaspoons of trans fats and 2 teaspoons of artificial flavoring. For each serving the company must set aside 10 cents. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:John ran out of pencils.  Where did  he go to get more? Choices:  A: desk drawer B: cup C: pencil case D: shelf E: office depot<n>Output:		 pencils<n><n>Input: Two guys are trying to finish their homework.  They need 100 hours to complete the task.  Time is in 5 minutes.   2 guys:  40 minutes each  20 minutes each  20 minutes every 5 minutes  20 minutes every 5 hours  40 minutes each.   5 guys:  90 minutes each   3 minutes each   5 minutes every 45 minutes.   45 minutes per minute.  You can do 10 questions   10 questions   50 questions   200 questions  25 questions   25 questions  300 questions  45 questions   30 questions<n>Input: 2 guys start work together to finish.  1 of them will need a spare pencil.  How many pencils will they need?  Outcome:<n>Input: (input) is 1 guy left with no spare pencil<n>Output:<n>Input: 1 guy has a spare pencil<n>Output: 1 guy is finished<n><n>Input: At a restaurant, two women have to serve the same customer.  If you are both seated next to each other, take the same order. If you are both not seated with each other, what should you order? What would be the total cost?<n>Output: If both are seated next to each other it will cost $0  If both are not seated with each other it will cost 80 + $0 = $160  If both are seated with each other it cost 60 - $0 = 80  If both are not seating with each other it will not be cost 1/160  If both are not sitting with each other it will be 1/890  If both are not standing next to each other it is 1/160<n><n>Input: A man wants to get rid of all the garbage he has collected over past 3 years.  What can he do?<n>Output: 1) take it home 2) dump it in the bin 3) recycle it 4) compost it

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:A wife asks a husband to stop being married to her, what is he likely to feel even with friends? Choices:  A: happiness B: pleasure C: happy D: grief E: isolation<n>Output:		 A Happy, with the one-third of joy.<n><n>Input:Adam sells 2 x 10 meters of cotton, he gets $50 for his work. He sells 2 x 10 meters for $100 a meter.  The first cost $1 to buy and is made available to him per month. Each time he goes to the market, he pays $1. The second cost $3 to buy and is made up with his work. So each time he shops, he gets $0.50. What is his annual income?<n>Output: Adam makes $200 a year<n><n>Input:Mary makes 30 dollars in income from her job.  She sells a total of 60 dollars of items in a year.  The average cost of her goods at retail is $2.70 per item, so she sells each retail good for only $2.20.  However, she sells 30 dollars.  What is Mary’s monthly income?<n>Output: $60<n><n>Input:Jim makes $300 a month on paper and $400 by trade. Because of this he needs to get a $1,000 cash loan.  How long can he get the loan?<n>Output: $1500<n><n>Input:Johnnie has a farm in his name, he earns 50 cents a day working with his brother.  He gets a pay-check every other week and splits it 50% to work on Johnnie’s farm and 50% to Johnnie’s wife.  How much does his brother earn?<n>Output: $120 a month, the other one hundred is split equally.<n>Thus Johnnie’s pay-check every other month gets $1200<n><n>Input:John and Mary have three kids that live with them. Their sons are in their twenties, the girls are in their teens. The parents can afford one bedroom apartment and pay only $25 per month for rent.  Their daughters live with their moms and are paying $50 each or $75 per month for rent. If they could move back to their house, they believe they would be happy living there. What would they pay for an apartment?<n>Output: $750<n><n>Input:John is on $100 a day, he earns $10 a day selling fruit on the counter at a local supermarket.  He also makes a commission from selling his goods in other stores.  A salesman walks by Johnnie, asks for his fruit, and asks Johnnie for a 10%. Johnnie takes the first 10%
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:Though nearby, an apple from an apple tree where would be an imported product to the USA? Choices:  A: ohio B: washington state C: alaska D: canada E: flowers<n>Output:		  An apple from a tree that you need to import.  It can only be shipped as a package.  A apple tree imported from washington state.  A apple tree that can be shipped as a package sent from washington state.<n><n>Input:Joe bought 12 kilograms of wheat (25 kg) and 7 kg of rice (10 kg).  A kilogram of wheat costs $0.75 and a kilogram of rice costs $0.50  After adding in transportation costs,  he paid $2/kg for both the wheat and the rice. How much did he pay for each item?<n>Output:Joe: 6.75 kg of wheat $2**70 = $80 [80*1.5]$80<n>So Joe spent $80/kg for his wheat and $80*1.5=$80*1.5=$120<n>So the final answer will is $120*$80=120<n><n>Input:John Ate 3kg of chicken and 3kg of chicken meat.  He spent 5 euros each for the items.  How much did he pay?<n>Output: $5.00 per kg (3.00/3.00)=$5.50<n>So the final bill is $7.50<n>[edit] Correct math answer with $3 per kg of bread.<n><n>Input:Derek bought three containers of cheese and 1 container of yogurt for 4 euros. He also got a deal at Costco that allowed him to get a half container of cheese for $2.63 so that was an extra $2.67. For the yogurt he bought the same containers of yogurt for $1.63. How much did he now owe on the three containers of cheese?<n>Output:$10.00 for the three containers = $21.63<n>So Derek spent $21.63 for his cheese and $21.63/3=56¢<n>That means if he wanted to buy the whole case of yogurt, he would end up spending $28.33. So the final price total for the cheese and yogurt is $27.33. So the total bill is $28.33 [edit]<n><n>Input:Johannes went to a movie, bought a drink and popcorn, and sat there for an hour and half.  How much did the movie cost him?<n>Output: He bought a drink and popcorn.   This movie was not too expensive (in fact the price was lower than the last movie)

One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week. How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane. How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:If done correctly grooming pet's nails generally does not cause this? B is 2 hours away from Bakersfield.  C is 3 hours away from Calexico.  D is 3.5 hours away from Bakersfeld.  Which three destinations are closer to A?<n>Output:A, B, C.  A, A, B.  C, C, C.<n>So A is 2 hours away.  B is 3 hours away.  C is 3.5 hours from Bakersfield.<n>So C is about 3 hours away.  D is about 4 hours away.  Then A is 4 hours away and B is 5 hours away<n><n>Input:In January, Bob was paid $14 per hour to clean the offices at his college. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week. How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane. How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:The person was looking up airline and hotel prices, what was he looking to do? How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:What would children do if they are bored? Choices:  A: walk B: change shoes C: play tag D: smell smoke E: reach over<n>Output:		   1 = 0 2 = 4 3 = 6 4 = 10 5 = 12 6 = 15 7 = 20 8 = 24 9 = 30<n><n>Solution key<n><n>Answer key:<n><n>1. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:Where is a good place to get a ball? Choices:  A: kitchen B: child's hand C: street D: toy store E: soccer game<n>Output:		 There are three of the same kind at Costco. How much would they all cost?<n>Input: The ball costs $30. How much are the balls costing at Costco?<n>Output: 30*30=<<80*30=160>>160<n>So the final answer in total for the balls is 160<n><n>Input:There are two new cars available for sale.  The models A and B cost $60,000 and $49,900 respectively.  Which of the following prices should be assigned to each car?<n>Output: The price to buy the cars is $110,000 and $69,900 respectively.  They cost 60 and 49 times their new prices.<n><n>Input:Mary works two jobs: one selling computer parts and building computers.  Her income is $300 per month.  She sells 10 computers per month at a price of $4000 each.  The new retail prices are $3000 and $2900.  There is another 50 computers that are built by her, but cost less.  How many computers could she sell at the new prices?<n>Input: 10*3*3000=3,300<n>Output: 3,300*3000 = 3,300*4000<n>So the final answer for the computers is 4<n><n>Input the prices of the above questions by using the calculator below. A "high" is an answer in Dollars and a "low" is an answer in Euros.

The cost of a single can of beer rose by $1.00 per can.  Would you reduce your cost of beer further, to 50 cents a can or to 50 cents a bottle?  If yes, how much would you lower your beer bill by?  Would you still reduce your beer bill when the price rose again three times when it comes back down?  If you said you would not change your drinking habits, the answer is No.  Why not? This is a serious problem in most countries – people not only drink too much, but they also pay their parents and/or the government to have them drink. If a person does not lower his or her buying habits, more and more taxpayers will have to subsidize that person.  So the answer is No<n><n>Input:Rice is one of the most common grain. It is usually grown in the central mountain range of Taiwan. The country has one of the fastest growing economies in the world. Why is rice grown in the mountains, instead of in the city where it could produce more?<n><n>Output:The price of rice is controlled to make living more affordable for poor and working class citizens. The poor eat rice mostly because they cannot afford other foods. In the past, the government used to buy rice for poor people in the city and sell it in the city for lower prices. The government would take the rice back and would provide food for free. The situation has changed since then. The government has decided not to provide food for free to poor people in the city. The government has decided to grow the rice itself in the mountains.  Most likely, the cost of rice is controlled to prevent people from starving to death. How many cars will he need for these things?<n>Output: He needs 3 cars 1 motorcycle 2 apartments 3 farm.<n>So he will have 5 cars, 4 apartments, 1 farm, $1000 in extra money, $2000 in extra money, and $4000 in extra money<n>That means his cars/apartments/apartments/farms will amount to this:<n>> 2 cars = ($4000-$4000)<n>> 1 motorcycle = ($4000-$2000)<n>> 2 apartments = ($2000-$2000)<n>> 1 farm = ($2000-$2000 + ($400-$1000))<n>> $1000 is only for extras<n>> $2000 is only for extras<n>So his extra-$$$$ comes out to be $400-$1000, depending on how many cars one has.<n>So the final correct answer has $4000 added to his budget.<n><n>Input: There are several different types of flowers in the same flowerbed, but they all bloom with different colors. Which one does this?<n>Output: Which one is this?<n>If this is a question of what type of flowers bloom, then what flower is the one with pink leaves?<n>If it is a question of how many types of flowers exist,
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:Where would you find a sign with some people lined up next to it? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:John just made first violin. So the final answer is 160<n><n>Input:James needs a car that gets 32 miles from one gallon of gas.  The gas industry told him it was easy to  figure out the miles using their estimates.  He also heard that people who get their gas changed often tend to drive the last mile because of how much  they save.  He decided to do that.  On average he gets 27 miles out of his car in one gallon of gas. What is his usage?<n>Output:James used to get 32**27 = 100***20 = 200<n>So he got 200**12 = 200*20 = 2000<n>So the final answer was 2000<n><n>Input:The price of gas jumped from 50 to 70¢ in the last two months. Choices:  A: exhilaration B: dismemberment C: spinal injuries D: getting wet E: splats<n>Output:		A - the cartoon character usually dies of shock<n>B - the cartoon character is decapitated<n>C - the cartoon characther is decapitated<n>D - one or both characters are dismembered<n>E - the cartoon characters falls off a cliff and splats<n><n>Input:What percentage of people were born in the 21st century vs in the 20th?<n>Output:>50%<n>>70%<n>>90%<n>>100%<n>>100%*<n>Percentage:<n>2.33%<n>2.02%<n>2.21%<n>1.88%<n>1.77%<n>1.77%-<n>Number:<n><n>Input:<n>Johns goes to the gym 3x per week and does not get any weight lifted.<n>Input:Johns goes to the dietician three times a week but no one ever gets an actual diet.<n>Output:<n>Johns starts a diet.  He has to keep himself on track (he eats less than 2500 calories a day and does not exercise).  He also has to go to the gym more often at least two times per week.<n>Output:<n>He goes to the gym 3 days a week.<n>He maintains his weight by consuming 2500 calories a day.<n>He goes to the dietician every three weeks.<n>At his third visit, the doctor prescribes an improved diet (Johns can consume more food and no longer gain weight).<n>Output:<n>He has lost 8 pounds in three weeks.  He weighs 175 pounds.<n><n>Input:<n>Peter travels to the mall to buy a gift for his brother - and he has to pay<n>$700.00<n>Output:<n>Peter pays $700 for a 25% discount.  The gift comes with a $500.00 gift card and $250.00 store credit.<n><n>Input:You are given two cans of tomato paste.  One is 10% concentrated tomato paste and the other 40%<n>concentrated tomato paste.  How many cans of whole tomatoes should you buy? *<n>Output:<n>Only one.  Use the 10% concentrated version to cook the rest:<n>Tomato paste = 40% cream (1 cup)<n>Total = 100 calories<n>5 cans of tomato paste = 10 calories (1/3 cup)<n>= 80 calories (1/4 cup)<n>= 90 calories (2/3 cup)<n>To get the full benefit of the 40% concentrated tomatoes, add 1 tbsp of olive oil to the pot.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:Where does a person need to get when they have more kids? You can only buy a family car which has one seat on each side.<n>So a double car is definitely unnecessary!<n>And twins make the most sense!<n>With twins, you have no need for the garage because you are all the same size!<n>Double the storage space!<n>And you can easily put all your stuff in the garage!<n>So double the space!<n>So the final answer would be 240*2=$<<360+240=480>>480<n>Or 480*3=$<<480*3=480>>480<n><n>Input:If Jim bought the same quantity of bananas as a family friend of his, how much extra would Jim pay when he bought bananas from his friend?<n>Output:<n>1 kilogram of bananas would cost Jim 1 $20<n>2 kg of bananas would cost him 1 $40<n>3 kg of bananas would cost 1 $60<n>In that case Jim would pay 2 $80<n><n>Input:When a man is laid up he is worried his wife is becoming bored. Where is the spoon placed on the plate?  (d) spoon is located on each side of the plate. How far is the spoon off of the plate? (e) spoon is located on the opposite side of all the other pieces of equipment.  How far is it away from all the other pieces?<n><n>Output:The spoon is placed one row back from the other food items.  This makes a bowl, not a serving dish<n>The food items are placed two rows apart from each other.  The spoon is located on the left-hand side of the row, one row back on the right-hand side.  This makes a serving dish<n>The plate is placed two rows behind the other item.  This makes a platter<n>The food equipment are placed face down on the plate, and the spoon is located just inside the dish.  This makes a spoon<n>The spoon is located directly under the rest of the food equipment. Someone please explain to me.<n><n>Click to expand...<n><n>A virus accomplishes its goals by infecting a host organism.<n><n>For example, a computer virus infects an entire computer system of several computers. A computer virus can't do anything without infecting a host. A virus has a limited power, but it needs a host.<n><n>A virus can make a computer malfunction, but that's only if the computer is infected, otherwise the computer does the necessary actions.<n><n>It is the same as a program on your computer; a program has it's own rules, but if you break or change them, the program can lose all it's functionality.<n><n>A virus does not actually move and is not affected by gravity (or in other words, it doesn't need gravity to move).<n><n>What I'm trying to say is that a virus could be programmed to "sit on" the computer and change all the files to have viruses, and change everything in a random way. In other words, it's all within the program itself.<n><n>The question is if the question asked is if there will be any change, and if there will be, how will that change affect the computer itself.

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane. Dinner<n><n>Input: The air conditioner is broken during the summer months.  This has led some workers to install a solar panel on their roof. It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:People are purposefully harming others, what trait are they exhibiting? Choices:  A: deceptive B: altruistic C: stupid D: cruel E: agressive<n>Output:		 Choices are evil. Evils are not good. Choices are good<n><n>Input:John is building a wall to put between the U.S and Mexico. The costs are not yet specified.  In all likelihood the total budget for the wall is $1.5 billion.  A more specific amount of budget is not discussed.  How much will it cost to construct and maintain a permanent wall?<n>Input: One kilogram of nuts would cost $24.  They would cost $40. (24 * $12) = $<<40>24*$12=36>>36<n>Output: For all nut purchases the total bill was $60.  It would double (40) * $48 = $480.<n>So an additional $480 was the added cost<n>To make his calculations more correct, I would give him 36 * $240 = 48<n>That was his total<n>Thus his final bill would have been 60<n>But it was less than 640<n><n>Input:The total number of hours spent at the gym was 24 hours per day at 5+times per week<n>Output: This was a correct answer. One of the answers was incorrect and so it is also incorrect.  Also we found that the total time was actually less than 24 hours per day, but that the times were only 5+times per week because one did one gym session plus one training session.<n>Output: We found one incorrect answer and so it is also correct.  If you get the answer wrong, you get a 100 point penalty point.<n>That was the correct answer for the first correct answer<n>With the correct answer we found there were an additional 4 incorrect answers.<n>Therefore there were 9 incorrect answers<n>That was 2 incorrect answers.<n>Thus there were 9 incorrect answers.<n>Therefore the total number of incorrect answers was 6.<n><n>Input: There are two children, both of whom are 5 years old. One weighs 100 pounds and the other 80. The father is unemployed. How much the mother has to earn to support the kids is $13,942.75 per year. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:After eating a dinner of uncooked chicken, what was felt by the poor man? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. If we only dream then we have fewer opportunities to learn new information or to make mistakes.  Thinking critically is the next best option to being alert.  If we are thinking critically then we learn quickly and quickly learn wrong.  Cross roads is the most useful action.<n><n>Input:  A is 6'2".  B is 6'4".  C is 6'5".  D is 6'6".  E is 6'8". Output: A's height is 6'4".<n>B's height is 6'3".<n>C's height is 6'2".<n>D's height is 6'1".<n>E's height is 6'0".<n>How can you account for an additional 5'6"?  Your response above will answer that question.<n><n>Input : John had 10 cans of tuna for dinner.  He was satisfied.  After dinner he took half a can of tuna for later.  How many cans do you think John has?<n>Output : John has 10 cans of tuna for breakfast and another 11 for lunch.<n>That means John has 11 cans of tuna total.<n>He could eat 11 twice a day for 5 days a week.<n>After 3 days, if John is still hungry, he can buy a 12 pack. How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:If one sees a fox and is standing in a landlocked, southern state, where is this person? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:Where would a ficus plant brighten up a room? For each mile Miles driven, it will cost $40 dollars and one trip (about 20 miles) will cost $30  When an odometer is added, the price per mile drops, however,  as the miles are added back in the odometer increases. He buys ten cars.  If he purchases each of the cars at twice the price, it will cost him $500 and he will save $50.  On his tenth car he adds an odometer.<n><n>Output:Miles driven by his car were $160-$60=$2-$40=$20-$30=$10=$30-$40=$20-$40=$30=$40=$40-$60=$150<n>Now that the cost of the car with odometer is $40, Miles that Dennis drove was $1,160-$40=$100, or $40 - $150=$30 = $80=$30. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:It was a vast complex, the launch pad was just one part of what? Choices:  A: movie B: cape kennedy C: space center D: military installation E: spaceship centre<n>Output:		<n>A: Movie<n>B: Cape Kennedy<n>C: Space center<n>D: Starship Centre<n>E: Space launch pad<n><n>Input:What is the cost of constructing the bridge from Singapore to Kota Kinabalu?<n>Output:The bridge cost $1,800,000<n>$240,000,000<n>$240/2=$240,000.000<n>$240,00,000<n>So the final answer of $240,00,000 is correct<n><n>Input: What is John's total daily income for the year?<n>Output:<n>Daily income: $36<n>Total income for the year: $200,000<n>That is correct<n><n>Input 1:<n>The total cost of the car is $11,000,000<n>The average cost of cars in Singapore is $13,600<n>So the estimated total cost of the car would be $11,600<n><n>Input 2:<n>The total cost, according to John, for the house was $200,000<n>The average price of houses (with tax) in Singapore is $2,400<n>So the estimated total house costs would be $21,400<n><n>Input 3:<n><n>Input 4:<n><n>Input 5:<n><n>Input 6:<n><n>Input 7:<n><n>Input 8:<n><n>Input 9:<n><n>Input 10:<n><n>Input 11:<n><n>Input 12:<n><n>Input 13:<n><n>Input 14:<n><n>Input 15:<n><n>Input 16:<n><n>Input 17:<n><n>Input 18:<n><n>Input 19:<n><n>Input 20:<n><n>Input 21:<n><n>Input 22:<n><n>Input 23:<n><n>Input 24:<n><n>Input 25:<n><n>Input 26:<n><n>Input 27:<n><n>input 28:<n><n>Input 29:<n><n>Input 30:<n><n>input 31:<n><n>Input 32:<n><n>input 33:<n><n>Input 34:<n><n>Input 35:<n><n>Input 36:<n><n>input 37:<n><n>Input 38:<n><n>input 39:<n><n>Input 40:<n><n>output 41:<n><n>input 42:<n><n>input 43:<n><n>input 44:<n><n>input 45:<n><n>Input 46:<n><n>input 47:<n><n>input 48:<n><n>input 49:<n><n>input 50:<n><n>Input 51:<n><n>input 52:<n><n>Input 53:<n><n>Input 54:<n><n>input 55:<n><n>input 56:<n><n>input 57:<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:A lonely man committed suicide, why would he do that? Choices:  A: suffering B: he was happy C: avoid problems D: unhappy E: end pain<n>Output:		 A: he was suffering B: he was not happy C: avoid problemsD: unhappyE: pain<n><n>Input:Joe went to the bank to open a loan. The loan will be for $1. When he gets the money, he buys an expensive car. Does it seem like a good idea?<n>Output: The loan is a good idea but he is spending too much, he needs to stop doing it.<n>So it seems like a good idea to stop his spending, because he is spending too much<n><n>Input:What is the average salary for a CEO?<n>Output: 50,000 dollars.<n><n>Input:How many people own 20 airplanes? Does the company that makes them earn 60% of the market share?<n>Output: 20<n>The company earns 60% of the market<n><n>Input:What does the average person use to buy food in this country?<n>Output: A bag of frozen meat (sliced), a sack of potatoes, two loaves of bread, milk, four litres of Coca-Cola, a five-pack of cigarettes, a six-pack of beer, 10 litres of Pepsi and two litres of Coke (total amount)
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:He wore the wrong shoes while walking all day, now he has what on his heels and toes? Choices:  A: exercise B: moving forward C: feet D: blisters E: locomotion<n>Output:		 He has the correct shoes.<n>However, the blisters caused his feet to stop moving, therefore making his shoes useless.<n>So the final, correct answer is he wore the wrong shoes<n><n>Input: He has an exercise bike that was recently bought. He spent 150 bucks on his membership at the gym.  The bike is worth $1500.  How much will his membership be worth in the future?<n>Output: He will be paying $1500 to use an exercise bike.  This is a significant amount, since the value of membership fees vary depending on the gym.  Therefore, he does not expect to continue the membership and is planning to cancel it upon the day of its expiration.<n>Output: He will have to decide if it is worth it to keep the membership.<n><n>*This could be incorrect if the question didn't have multiple options. For example, one choice could be that the exercise bike's value is 50 dollars. If both of those choices are correct, no other answers can be given correctly.

He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane. He thought the mascot’s name was a cow.<n>He thought she was a cow and named it Cindy. Later, as he grew up and got more knowledge of the animal, it was now a giraffe and he named it Bob.<n><n>Input: If a cow is called a cow, then so is a giraffe a giraffe. A child's understanding of the animal is therefore a positive indicator that the child is smart and able to make an educated guess about what the animal's true name is. The child should be rewarded for their effort. Which option follows then?<n>Output: If a child knows the animal's true title is a cow, then they deserve to be rewarded for their effort and should be awarded a prize if given the chance.<n><n>Input 1: What happened when he walked into the room and saw the girl and her friend dressed up as a monkey and a dog?<n>Output: He felt embarrassed, he wanted to make a run for the door. His friends told him she was a monkey.<n>Input 3: He immediately regretted being rude, he apologized to her and brought home a monkey doll. He knew he could not be the only one who enjoyed being a monkey.<n>Input 4: When a teacher asks the class what they think of when they look at a girl, the child should be praised for understanding that girls are girls, and a girl looking pretty doesn’t always mean being a cat or a dog (a boy).<n>Output: He knew girls are girls and looked pretty to make a friend. He would not feel embarrassed when a girl was nice to him.<n><n>Input1. The girl went into a bookstore and bought a book entitled, ‘Are men dogs and dogs men?’  She read the title page and asked her mother “So what does this book tell me?”, she was then led by the mother into the bookstore. They soon came to a man. He was standing opposite the book and reading and his face revealed something unexpected for him. Instead of reading the title page, it looked like a dog. He walked towards the girl and picked her up as she was a cow. They soon went to the restroom and she was asked by the cashier “So what does he teach you today?” It turns out the girl did learn something. The man said “The answer is simple, dogs are men like cows are men.�

How many years did he serve in prison for his second?<n>Output: 50*3=<<50+3=200>>200<n>That means the man spent 200 of his years, or 2 weeks, in prison for committing his first offense.<n>That means he has spent 200 years on his second offense<n>Therefore,<n>1000/(200+2)/200 = 1000<n>1000 = 1000*3=<2000*3=$1200<n>Therefore,<n>1200/1000 = 1200<n>Therefore, the final answer is 1200<n><n>Input: A family has 6 grandchildren, 5 boys named John and one girl named Helen. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:Where can the legs of a stool be built? D: building<n>Input:How many minutes does it take for a basketball to go from 12 feet on the floor to 12 feet in the air? Answer: 12 seconds<n>Output:How many times does it take for an elephant to cover 4 football fields? B is a stadium.  C is a movie theater.  D is a bus.<n>Finally, E is a bus<n><n>Input:John buys 3 kg of nuts and 2.50 kg of dried fruits at a supermarket.  One kilogram of nuts cost $12 and one kilo of dried fruits cost $8. How much does his purchases cost?<n> Output: For the nuts he paid $12 * $12 = $▪▪▪▫1.5* $8 = $▪▣▪▫2.5* $8.5 = $▪▥▪▪▬2.5* $48.5 = $▜▪▪▭▪▣□□□▝<n>So his purchases cost $▪▣ ▬2.5*$48.5 = $ ▛▼▪▫3.5* $48 =$▛▼▬2 +▛▼▪3 + ▛▼▲▪▫3 + ▛▲▪▪▽ + ▛▼ ▪▼ ▪▲▪▽ +▛▼ ▪>>▲▪▣▝ + ▛▼ ♦▼ ▪▴▢▢▢▣▢▢▧▢□□▞▞▞▟▣▣▃▟▛▲▲▲▴▣▟▲▌ ▦▲▽ ▨▿ ▦▲▼ ▙▲▵ ▩▲▲▤▲▴▘▿▿▿▼▲▼▲▶ ▦▲▶ ▨▿ ▨▾▿ ▨▿ ▛▼▿ ▣ ▛▼▽▽ ▛▼▥▼ ▫▪▹▪▹▥▪▹▢□▥□□▗▗▗▓▗▓▓▓▗▜▗▜▝
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:What are students trying to do? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:The detective had to analyse all the clues, every little thing at the scene he had to what? When a staff member extracts the card from the safe, a number flashes on the reader.  The staff member then enters this number into the computer and returns to his desk.  When the card is extracted from the safe, the process repeats itself.  When the codes are entered into the computer, the computer returns the card to the safe.  If you would have withdrawn the card to a different register from where you placed it in the safe, it would probably not have been removed.  If you have a safe with several locks, you may not be able to remove all the locks or lock one of the other locks at any one time.<n>Output: The card reader is set to a number that you must match to unlock the door.  This number appears on the reader when it has been inserted, and appears again when it is extracted.  When you extract the card, the reader also appears.  Each time these two items are activated, the computer will print a number in the mainframe screen that corresponds with the key number you have inputted.  If you have entered the correct code at the same time each time the card is extracted, then the computer has an alphanumeric match and the card is returned to the safe (receipt). How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:Where can you store you tent and keep it on your person? Choices:  A: sleep in while camping B: camp ground C: woods D: bag E: backpack<n>Output:		 To store your tent and keep it on you person you must buy the large canvas canopy (canopies were $2.50)  The canopies hold 2 pax in each other  This makes the price $3.50  And for your sleeping bag you must buy the 4 pax tent bag (canopies were 49 cents)  The price of the bag is $2.50  The bag now holds 3 pax (which are 10 dollars)  So the final answer is 48<n><n>Input:John runs a car washes. He buys $10 thousand worth of cars per year. He has to have the cars back in a minimum of 4 weeks. How long does it take him to have his cars done?<n>Output: He takes 48 hours to have his cars done  But as you can see the cars should be done in 4<n>Hours  24 = 80 = 240<n>So the final answer should be 480<n><n>Input:Bob wants to keep 2 cars at his house while he is working on his house. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:Billy went away because his parents were fighting and he didn't want to stay where? Choices:  A: home team B: present C: at home D: come back E: charming<n>Output:		 He decided to stay at home.<n>What does A, B, and E mean?<n><n>Input:Billy has always wanted to play hockey since he was a young boy. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week. He produces 1.6 cubic meters of hay per hour.  His cost per cubic meter is $100.  His costs per head are $20.  How many heads of hay does he produce?<n>Output: The hay would cost $200/3*3=<<200/3=8>>8 so his total output would be 8/3=<<80-120=160>>1.2<n>So his output now is 160*7=$<<80*7=240>>240 per hour<n><n>Input: James goes fishing every weekend. How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:The old barn was beyond repair, they had to destroy it before they could what a new one? What could you sell instead?<n>Output: A few different options: rent, sell your stuff, and build a new house<n>Input:  How much does it cost to buy the average house in a US city?<n>Output: The median price in the US is $184,640<n>So the median house cost about $184,640, or just under 1 million dollars<n>A house that starts construction today costs roughly $100,000<n>So the median new home cost $900,000<n>One house that went up in building costs is a few hundreds of thousand more, a bit less than a million dollars<n>so now its just under 1 million bucks<n>If we want to buy a used house it usually costs more than 250k, but sometimes more than 1 million<n>so to make up for the difference in cost we need to sell stuff so more money is left over.<n><n>Output: How much is your average credit score? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:The lady was getting worked up about the article explaining the uptick in accidents in their area, but her husband was dismissive of it stating that accidents what? Choices:  A: happen to people B: hurt people C: happen anytime D: happen often E: happen anywhere<n>Output:		 Accidents are B+D.  There were 4 A crashes in their area.  There were also 3 crashes.<n>So for this particular crash 4 A crashes happen in its area<n>So the final answer for this particular crash is 1.29.<n><n>Input:Peter buys a two-kilogram sack of apples from a store. A kilogram of apples costs $1.99.<n>Output: His purchase price was $1.99, $2 for 1 kilogram.<n>Multiply his purchase price by 20 cents to get the kilogram price before accounting for taxes ($1.99 x 100%).<n>So his purchase price was $1/1=$3<n>Multiply the purchase price then by 20 cents to get a kilogram price ($2.99/1) before taxes ($1.99/1).  Multiply again by 20 cents to get $2/2 = $3.<n>Multiply again ($3 $3 $1) times 20 to get $3/3 = $3<n>Multiply again $3 / 20 = $3/3 =$3.66<n>Multiply again twice ($3 $3) / 20 = $7.67<n>Multiply it again ($3 / 20.66) +$7/20 = $8<n>Multiply twice ($3 / 20.00) / 20 = $10.00<n>Multiply twice (8 $10) / 200 = $400<n>What is your final answer?<n><n>Input:The salesman went to a hardware store. First he purchased some screws at the store and some rope to tie a tarp on the roof of the car he wanted to sell to a farmer.<n>Output: He purchased the same quantity of screws as he wanted but some other items as well. He purchased the same quantity as he wanted.<n>Multiply purchase prices x 20 = $4 = $16.<n>Multiply this by $4 (2nd $16) multiplied by 20 = $28<n>Multiply purchase price x 20x 20 = $72.06<n>Multiply purchase amount x 20 - $72 = $24.96<n>Multiply purchase ($24 96) x 20 = $8.24<n>Multiply purchase (8 $16) x 20 = $60.92<n>Multiply purchase per unit ($80) = $2.50<n>Multiply purchase x 20 - $60 = $21.10

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:The gambler had been winning a lot, he wisely decided to what? Choices:  A: matchwinning B: cash in C: compete D: return E: celebrate<n>Output:		 The gambler increased his total earnings by $200*2=$<<200$.2=$40 >>40>40 and took home $280<n>So his total earnings go up $200*2=$/$<<200$.2=$20>>20 and take home $280<n>So the final answer $280<n><n>Input:When the new restaurant opened last week, it got great reviews, the staff were excited.  They already have their reservations for Monday to Tuesday.  However, the restaurant had only been open 7 days! What is the problem?<n>Output: Because there was a problem, the restaurant didn't open Monday or Tuesday.<n><n>Input:The man and his family have just returned from a three month trip.  They had spent 10 out of all 10 months on vacation.  Over the course of the 10 months they visited a large number of different countries.   They have lived in the U.S. for one year.  This year they plan to visit Canada and Europe.   How many months over the first 10 years did his family have in the U.S.?<n>Output: Three<n><n>Input:The baker is starting to feel depressed.  His wife is dying at 67, her health isn't good, and it seems they will be going to college in the fall.  He started to worry because he can't afford another wedding cake.  So he decided to retire today.  He is going to try to start a business and sell his cakes by the end of January.  What business should he start?<n>Output: Bread<n>It is called Bakery Biz<n><n>Input:The waiter is working overtime to make up for lost time.  Over the course off the year he has worked 3 weekends, 3 holidays, 12 weekday evenings and 12 weekend midday hours. Total overtime hours: 56 hours in a year.  How much overtime does he get over the course of a year?<n>Output: He gets $28.72 (56 * 56 = $28.72 over the course of a full year)<n>So for overtime he will get payed $28.72 a month or $2,112 over a year<n>That is a total of $3,112 over 1.5 years<n>So the final answer$28.72<n><n>Input:Joe was the president of a company. He was always busy, but now he is running behind on projects and can't seem to complete them on time.  So he wants to step down before he takes any
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:Where would you get a bag after someone fills it with clothes? Choices:  A: shopping cart B: cashier C: shopping mall D: supermarket E: bookstore<n>Output:		 The customer bought 10 bags of clothes.  Then they filled all the bags with the next size clothes.  Then they sold the clothes in the shopping mall.  This cost them $170.<n>Output: He paid 170*$9-<>$11=$<<170+10*+11=>190>>190.<n>So the final answers are all 190<n><n>Input: How are you going to do your taxes?  You'll have 2 years to file, but you still won't know how much you owe even after taxes are paid.  Are you going to file it yourself?  Get help from a tax professional?<n>Output: He'll pay $1000.  That's a refund.<n>Output: He'll work 3 years to pay it back.<n><n>Input:What is the total time it takes to fill a container?  Input: 8 gallons of diesel fuel Cost: $40.  Shipping time: 4.5 months<n>Output: One container's worth of diesel will cost $16.  Shipping is $30.<n>Output: One container will take 5 months to fill.    That's 2 months' work.<n>Output: He will wait 6 months to fill it. That takes him 8 months of work.<n><n>Input: How long it takes you to fill a tank?  Input: 7 gallon of gasoline Cost: $15.00 Shipping: 8.5 months<n>Output:- One gallon of diesel will cost $30. Shipping takes 2 months.<n>Output:- One gallon diesel will take 8.5 months of work. That is 2 months' work. 2 months' work. 5 months. 6 months. 12 months. 21 months. 25 years.<n><n>Input: Who fills the gas?  Input: A grocery store employee. Cost: $1.00 Shipping: 8 Months Cost: $10.00<n>Output: One gallon of gas is full at the end of 8 months and has a cost of $10.00.<n>Output: He can fill it for 2 more months and have it cost him $13.00<n>Output: He needs to change the tire and replace the oil about once a week, but he has the money to do that. If his only other activity is driving a tractor he just needs to bring tools with him to put in the tire and replace the engine oil with gas.  He can fill the tire and oil for about $10.00 a week.<n>Output: One gallon will be used about once

One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane. John made her a cheese soup because she wasn’t very hungry and because he loves her.  The day came and John got home and he heard his wife’s car drive up before he walked out.
