It also stores about 3.5 billion gold ingots.<n>Output: 60% of the gold reserves will be sold every year.  The surplus will be sold off.<n>Output: The Treasury will eventually be bankrupt, but the gold will be left as collateral for private creditors.<n><n>Input: Where is the strategic fuel reserve in the U.K.? Choices:  B: tankers C: tankers D: trucks E: tankers<n>Output: The Strategic Petroleum Reserve at Fort Breckenridge has 1.7 billion pounds of liquid fuel (1.3 billion in gasoline and 672 million in diesel) in storage.<n>Output: 60-65% of the fuel will be exported.  The rest will be kept in the bank.  The Strategic Petroleum Reserve has no value.<n>Output: All the stockpiled fuel has been burned.<n>Output: There will be no surplus of liquid fuel in the United States.  The Strategic Petroleum Reserves will be depleted.<n><n>Input:Where are the strategic weapons stockpile storage? Choices:  A.  the Strategic Missile Storage Facility (SMSF) B.  the Strategic Forces Development Facility (SFDP) C.  the Military Engineering Base (MEB) D.  the Naval Strategic Petroleum Reserve (NSP)<n>Output: The Strategic Weapon Supply Center (SWS) and the Naval Facilities Engineering Center (NFEC) are both located at the SMSF.  The SMSF is used to store missile guidance computers.  The SFDP is used to keep diesel and aviation fuels.  The MEB is used to keep oil as well as gasoline and diesel fuel.  The Navy has plans to expand the MEB and add additional bunkers for fuel.<n>Input: The location and size of the Naval Strategic Petroleum Reserve at Fort Worth is uncertain.  There is likely a stockpile at Fort Lewis.  There is also a Strategic Petroleum Reserve at Naval Station Jacksonville and one at Naval Station Mayport.<n>Output: Fort Worth stocks 100 million gallon tanks of diesel oil, and there may be a stockpile at San Diego.  There is also probably a stockpile at Naval Station Mayport, but they cannot locate it easily.<n>Output: The military has plans to buy tanks to use in operations in countries

Choices:  A: show B: theatre C: hockey game D: movies E: event<n>Output:		 Soccer B Hockey C Drama D Movies E Event<n><n>Input:What was the first movie Adam ever witnessed with a friend in the theater?  A: "The Godfather" and a girl sitting next to him at the cinema<n>Output: "Tropic Thunder"<n>So he and a friend watched "Tropic Thunder". ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:If electrical equipment won't power on, what connection should be checked? Output: Will they still be worth anything?<n><n>Input:<n><n>Input:<n>2 children were having a picnic with their dogs. They decided to invite other people to the picnic.  Their parents decided they would play games while the children played baseball. Who should they invite?<n>Output:<n><n>Input:  1<n><n>Input:<n>1/6^2/2(1+2)+2<n>Input:<n><n>Output:  (4-3)*3=1/6^2<n>Input:<n>Input: (3-2)*3=1/4^2<n>Input:  Input: 3<n><n>Output:<n>(1+3)*4=1/2^2<n>Input: Input: 4<n><n>Output:<n>1+2=2/4<n>Input: Input: 1<n><n>Output:<n>Input:.<n>Input: Input: 2<n><n>Output:<n>3=2+3<n>Input: Input: 3<n>Output:<n><n>Output:<n>7=5<n>Input: Input: 6<n>Output:  7=5<n>Input: 3 + Input: 6<n>Input: Input: Input: 9<n>Output:<n>Input = 3 + Input: 6 + Input: 9 + Input: 9 +<n>Input: Input:<n>Input = Input + Input + Input: + Input: + Input<n>Input = Input + 3 + 3 + 3 +<n>Input = Input + 1 + Input: 2 + Input: 2 +<n>Input = Input = Input + 7 + Input: + Input + 1 + Input + Input<n>Input = 2 + Input + 2 + Input: 2<n>Input = 4 + Input: Input: 4<n>Input = 2 Input: Input: 2<n>Input: 2 Input: Input: Input: Input<n>Input = 3 Input: Input: 3<n>Input = Input Input
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:The teachers needed to get their classrooms ready for the school year.  What is one thing they might do? Choices:  A: talk too much B: teach children C: open boxes D: answering questions E: giving homework<n>Output:		 One thing they might do is to talk too much they cost 140<n>And teaching children cost 140/1=<<140/1=20>>20<n>So each 1 hour class cost 140<n>And answering questions cost 20<n>So each hour class cost 20 + 1*1*20 = 60<n>So each hour class costs 60 + 20*1*60 = 120<n>So each class costs 120<n>And there is no homework<n>So which 5 out of those 12 are your guess to be the correct answer, because every question is more confusing than the last. Your guess is as follows:<n>A: talk too much B : open box C: teach children D: open boxes E: open boxes F: answer questions<n>So you are telling me they all cost 140, you are right.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:Where can you purchase food and eat it at tables? Choices:  A: house B: fast food restaurant C: library D: conference E: paper<n>Output:		 A house C fast food restaurant and conference<n>And if you ask a group of people what is their preferred place to eat, most will say house B unless they were hungry when their assigned question began asking about food<n>Also the group B option makes more sense when you know that people tend to eat in groups. Therefore, house B seems more important<n><n>Input:Where do you sit for dinner?  You need to buy 2 sets of dining sets.  This requires two dishes.  You put the dishes into a box and your waiter/waitress brings them to you.  How many items do you need in your meal?<n>Output: 2 x 12 = 24<n>You need to buy 2 sets if you want the full meal you are assigned for (which is 4).  You can buy 2 additional dishes for your own meal.  So you buy 2 boxes.<n>So the final set of meals was 3 x 24 = 72<n>I think you might have more questions about the dishes.  Are you sure?
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:If you socialize by having trivial conversations it is called what? Choices:  A: make friends B: mingle C: meet people D: small talk E: meet new people<n>Output:		If you socialize (A) by having trivial conversations or (B) by making friends (C) then you get to meet people. Making friends (D) gives you a larger social circle.  If you socialize by mingle then you are in a social environment.  If you socialise by meeting new people then you get to do (A) and (B) simultaneously. Meeting new people (E) gives you a smaller social circle<n>That means A<n>Final answer: D

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:If a person is seeing new things, what do they most often feel? She spends $100 on new clothes while she is wearing the jumpsuit.  How much will her clothing bill cost?<n>Output: The total cost for new clothes + $100 = $10.<n>So her total bill is $10 * $100 => $11 => $11.50  +$100 => $17 => $17.50<n>The total cost for all her clothes plus the new jumpsuit is $17 * $10 = $17.50.<n>So her bill was $17 * $10 => $17.50 * 10 => $17.50  = $1750<n>Since this is double what she spent prior to the jumpsuit, she loses money.<n>The final answer is 1750 + $17 * $10 * $10 * $170 => $1780<n>Since she did not have any clothes to begin with, she wins because the bill was much higher than what she would pay for clothes (more than double)

Choices E, D, and ABC will produce all A+.  Choices ABC and F will produce ABC+.  Choices F#, D, ABC-F, and B\F# are each only produced for ABC.  For D the only three options are:  A: factory (also found at B) or university (found at C) or B: grocery store (also found at C) or C: shop (found at D).  Finally, for ABC-F at C there are only 2 locations, that being at C and at A.  Choices F# at A only produce ABC+.   For F-C, F# only produce ABC+.  There are no A+ at F#.  In general, manufacturing operations at the different locations are similar, although at one factory A will produce A-F while at the other C-E A+ will be produced there.  A+ produces more than 100-200 units a year in total.  A-F produces less than 50 units.  E and F# will produce up to 200 units a year each.  ABC at ABC will produce F-E, F-E at F# will produce F, and F-E at ABC-F will produce F-A.   Choices ABC and A-E will both only produce the units for ABC+<n>Input: A+ provides a service that people are willing to pay for. Choices:  A+ provides a product people want.  B** provides a service that people want.   C: factory provides a service people are willing to pay a premium for. Choices: C+ provides a product people are willing to pay more for.  D: grocery store provides a service that people would pay more for. Choices: D+ provides a product people would pay more for, and F# provides a service people would pay more for or F.  E: aircraft provides a service, often at a premium price, that people would pay more to have. Choices: E+ provides a product people might pay more than to have, and F allows for a premium to be charged for any premium.   It can be seen that B can be considered a service and a product, and A and F could be considered a service and an object and a product.<n><n>Input:
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:You'd add pepper and salt to what liquid meal if it's bland? Choices:  A: supermarket B: water C: cellars D: soup E: grocery store<n>Output:		 Pepper and salt can be added to a bland liquid meal.<n><n>Input: How much money does someone with $50,000 worth of assets have if they own a 1.5-month-lease on a car?<n>Output: The car is worth $50,000.  So $50,000 * 1.5 months = $120,000.  This means the first 4 months of operating his car are $120,000 * $50,000 = $270,000, which is twice as much as the previous year’s earning.  This is enough to pay for his $50,000 car lease.  A car with a $50,000 price increase is worth $1,150,000.<n><n>Input: The dollar amount of your house will go up by $100,000 once you add a $350,000 appraisal.  You can't do that without buying that house.  How much money ($100,000) will you earn if you buy that house at that price?<n>Output: The $300,000 house, plus $350,000 * 1.25 = $650,000.  So you earn $650,000 * 25% = $2,350,000.  This equals $4,500,000 that you don't pay taxes on.  It's more than a million more than you earned in the first six months you had the house.  So the final answer is $2,350, 000 ($2,350, 000/26 = $4,500, 000.)<n><n>Input: If you work for the school board, which job would you consider harder?<n>Output: The hard job would probably be the one that doesn't involve kids or work.  I would probably choose the job with the fewest students.  I think that the hardest job would be the one that had the biggest budget, because there would be so many more kids.  But I think I would rather have the job with the low budget.  What are your thoughts?  Is this as hard as it sounds to you?<n><n>Input: 1) How many kids will be in the new high school building by 1999?<n>Output: The numbers aren't really important right now.  That's why we can't do a $250,000 budget to begin with.<n>The numbers are important because that's the number of students we plan to build<n><n>Input: 2) What do you think is more important to education, money
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:Where can you get a stray small dog? Choices:  A: living room B: animal shelter C: georgia D: pet shop E: dog show<n>Output:		 You can pick any of the 1 (a) or 2 (a) answers!<n>Input: In a pet store you choose the animal shelter to get a stray dog. The price is $22.50.<n>Output: The final answer is 2250<n><n>Input: A man named Andy has a job interview with a law firm. The hiring manager says that after he looks into Andy's background, he doubts that he has the work ethic for the job. If this is true, what does this say about Andy?<n>Output: He is a lazy slacker who does not want to work.<n><n>Input: What does a professional wrestler call one of his rivals? His enemy is "Hawk Eye".<n>Output: He says to be "Hawk Eye" (see above).<n><n>Input: Which animal has the longest tail in the world?  Answer: A: rhino B: raccoon C: leopard D: dog E: snake<n>Output: The answer to the question is Rhino. The tail measurement is 28 inches.<n><n>Input:Where does the sun rise and set? Answer: The east gets the most sunlight during the day but is the sun highest in the sky during the night.<n>Input: The sun sets from west and goes directly west to east.<n>Output: The sun rises at east and goes directly east.<n><n>Input: A person who loves dogs and is very devoted to them wants to spend at least 8 hours/day exercising them. To get that much exercise, what price must the person pay for those exercise facilities?<n>Output: The maximum price for the exercise facilities is $300 per month.<n><n>Input:Which vegetable, known commonly as a "peanut," is used to top its own jelly? The answer is watermelon.<n>Output: Watermelon is a fruit, not a nut. The best topping for the watermelon is peanut butter.<n><n>Input: Where do you find a new person to help with your project? You can call at the phone number below. Or you can visit the website listed.<n><n>Output: You call the number below and the person you get will be willing to help at a discounted rate. The phone number below is 2-1-1.<n>Input: You call the number listed and they give you a free consultation.<n>Output: You do not pay the person for their free consultation. The only thing that he can do for you is give you the number below. This number is 1-866
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:What do people want to do when they love a place that they are going on vacation in? Choices:  A: pleasant thoughts B: overspending C: moving there D: staying there E: debt<n>Output:		 A must take a nap B must drive C must make a statement D needs to enjoy going there<n>That means that the final answer is D + E<n><n>Input: Which of the following does not qualify as a restaurant?<n>a.) A hotel B.) A grocery store C.) A drive-thru D.) A vending machine<n>Output: A hotel + a grocery store + a vending machine = A restaurant<n><n>Input: Which is the first product that you think of when you think about getting a drink in the evening; wine, iced tea, beer, or a soft drink?<n>Output: What beverage would you replace soft drinks with?<n><n>Input: The price of wheat went up from $30 to $40 a bushel.  Which meal is the most expensive?<n>Output: It was the meal for the family of 6 that had dinner at a restaurant.<n>This means that the final answer will be meal for 6 for $40<n><n>Input: Which does not make a good car insurance policy for people going on vacation?<n>a.) You can drive everywhere. b.) The policy covers loss and damage only. c.) The insurance includes collision damage as well.<n>Input: You can drive everywhere.<n>Input: The policy covers loss and damages only.<n>That means that the car insurance for going on vacation is not a good policy.<n>Input: You do not drive everywhere.<n>Output: So it will cost 10x more to drive on vacation than driving on a normal time,<n>So it will cost 10x as much to drive on vacation than normal<n><n>Input: Which one of the following would you pick to carry a baby or a child?  a.) Car,  d.) Car seat  b.) Car dongle  c.) Boats dongle<n>Output: a., c.) or b.<n>Input: A dongle b.) a dongle<n>Input: Car A dongle Car B dongle<n>Output,  Car dongle<n>Input, Car B dongle Car C car A<n>Output, Car B Car dongle Car D dongle
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:Where can someone purchase a contraceptive device without a prescription? I will change question to cost. thank you<n>Output: A:  pharmacyB:  person C: person D: pharmacyE: personF: personG: personH: personI: personJ: personN: personO: personP: personQ: personR:  personH: I will edit the question to cost. thanks.<n><n>Input:Wherecanone purchase a contraceptivedevice withouta prescription? One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:Where can you buy socks and jeans? Airport<n>2. Shopsmart<n>3. Shopping mall<n>4. Clothing store

It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:James used the cannon to shoot at something while seeking lunch. It was overkill.  What did he shoot at? Choices:  A: body armor B: ungulate C: bomber D: kill people E: animal<n>Output:		 A because he thought it was the most extreme thing he could think of to shoot at.  B because he got lucky and found a cow at his target C because he saw a cow A because there were cows B because someone else had the same plan B because there were no cows C because there are cows D because there aren't any cow at all E because he is weird<n><n>Input: Jane went shopping and bought 3 pairs of pants. They cost $15 each because they were the largest of the three sizes she bought.  She didn't buy any of them because they were too short for 2 of them.  The pants cost $10 each because they only held up the waist of one pair.  She spent $100 on pants. The total cost was $160 for 3 sets of pants.  What is Jane's income?<n>Output: Jane purchased 3 sets of pants that cost $160. The total for Jane's three sets was $0.<n><n>Example:<n>John Smith went to a store that sold cheap goods and tried on jeans.  He found that he liked a pair he tried on and bought them.  However, he didn't know how much each pair of jeans cost until he read the price in the store.  He paid full price for the jeans because he just wanted the jeans to fit and wear.  He never realized that he could just buy 2 of a pair and resell them for 20% off the original retail price.  John then resells these for a 100% profit.<n><n>Input: Jane was charged $10 for an umbrella.<n>Output: Jane paid $10 for her umbrella. The total price was $20.<n><n>Input:James went to the grocery store, and while there he noticed that there were two different brands of spaghetti.  He selected the second brand because it was more expensive.  The second brand cost $6 more than the first.  How much overall did James spend on the spaghetti?<n>Output: James paid $6.60 for spaghetti.<n><n>Input:Jane is pregnant and wants to get pregnant.  However, she doesn't want to use the pill because she doesn't want her body to get pregnant for her.  She also doesn't want condoms because she doesn't want to get raped.  She doesn't want to get an abortion because she doesn't want the baby.  How did she achieve these things in order to get pregnant?<n>Output: She used the pill for a month and never had a baby.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:James was a student who had a report that is due tomorrow.  Where might he spend most of his time today? Choices:  A: university B: college class C: class room D: classroom E: library<n>Output:		 He has plenty more classes to go before he finishes the report<n>That means he spends the most time at each of the places in D and classroom E<n>They are all still in class and he spends the least time in class B.<n>That means D and E are the next least favorite<n><n>Input:James has to run to the train station every two days.  There are trains departing every 3 hours after 10am.  He now has to buy 2 tickets so that he can use them the second and the third day  How much does it cost?<n>Output:The overall cost increased 2 and half times:2.5x$40=5.25<n>So his overall cost is $5.25 - 2.5x$40 = $4<n>So he spends $4 more a day for the tickets<n>So the final answer has to be $4 or $4.25<n><n>Output:For an employee making $18,400 per year and spending 4 hours each day at work, the total amount of money he is worth for the month is $5,200.<n>How much money is left for the next month after expenses?<n>Output:$5,200 +$18,400=$6,700<n><n>Input:James goes to the grocery store and buys 7 oranges.  He must use some.  What is the best method of storing them?  He should use paper towels. He should use his fists. He should stack them on the floor.  How much does it actually cost?<n>Output: Each orange is $10.  So the value of each orange is $10.25 ($10 * 7 * $7 = $10.25).<n>If he purchases 100 oranges, he only spends $1,150 for them (5 * $10.25 = $1,150)<n>So their total cost of $1,150 = $1.25, or an increase of $150<n>Therefore their total value is $0.25<n>And therefore their total value is $-1/(2+$1)<n>Therefore their value minus their value is $-1<n>Therefore their value is -$1<n>Therefore their value divided by 2*2 = -1<n>Therefore their value less 2*2 = -$1*2/2<n>Therefore their value divided is $0.25 /2 = (2 * 2*2) / 2<n>Therefore their total value minus total value divided is $0<n>Therefore their total value divided is -
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week. It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:His running escape didn't last long once he tripped, perhaps he should've thought to what? How many people have phones in America?  The total number of phones sold in America is 100 million.  How many of those 100 million people have a phone with a certain name? The answer is 20,000,000, 000.  This means that not a single number is smaller than 20K.  So the final answer is 20,000 K units.  Why?  In this case it would be impossible for each and every number to be less than 20K.<n>Input: How many people has John in America?  The number is 100,000.  How old is John? Because this answer does not work if there are any numbers smaller than 20K.<n><n>Input: In the grocery store the milk cost $0.99, the cheese cost $0.79, and the bread cost $3.99. Which one of these items costs less than $4?  Output: The cheese does not cost $4 because the other two cost $4 each.  Therefore the milk costs less $0.99 than $3.99 and the bread is more $0.79 than $3.99.  Averaging $0.99 of each one, the total cost is $3.99.<n>Output
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:What type of water transportation is human powered? Choices:  A: turn away B: let down C: have to sleep D: run E: row boat<n>Output:		  D) waterboat       Because there is no engine to pull the boat it can't run<n>Therefore  it can't row
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:If you're standing in line and the line isn't moving what might you feel? Choices:  A: order B: queueing up C: wait turn D: fatigue E: anger<n>Output:		 It's an endless line full of people taking turns in line. Therefore, if you can, always queue up.<n><n>Input: A couple of years ago, the owner of a restaurant that serves Mexican food had a problem with the employees because they were too busy.  He gave them 100% of their earnings as wages.  Now half of them are fired.  How much money would he have saved if he hadn't fired them?<n>Output: To save 50.5% he would have saved 80%<n><n>Input:The following table shows the following prices:<n>Bake sale-1 pound of pie 60.00 Shasta lemon pudding, 3.00<n>Bounce house, 2.00 Hot dog, 1.00 Slice of pizza, 16.00<n>Candy bar, 1 pack 2 dozen cookies, 4.00<n>Dress up, 12 pack of puffy jackets, 4.00<n>Frodo goes to a ball game and the weather is cold. If you have a jacket, what would you take with you? Answers:  (1) A sweater<n>(4) A scarf<n>(9) My hoodie<n>Frodo's costume makes it hard to walk up the stairs. Which one of the following options is the best way to carry Frodo around? Answers:  (7) Bag<n>(14) A pack<n>(16) A pack and some rope<n>(18) Frodo's cloak<n>What was Frodo's age 20 years ago when he arrived for Middle-Earth? Answers:  19<n><n>Input: If you're at a restaurant and a waiter gives you an incorrect bill, how would you handle it?<n>Output: If the bill is 2.00 then I'll ask the waiter to leave and then I'll pay the 2.00.<n><n>Input:The cost of electricity for the average US household is $0.90 per kilowatt hour.  The cost of gasoline for the average American household is $0.80 per gallon.  The average car consumes around 12000 miles of gas a year.  The average car travels about 6,000 miles per year.  Calculate the price of a gallon of gas used to buy a new car in the US. Answers:  $2.75<n>(3) $4.15<n>(4) $4.99<n>(5) $4.79<n>(6) $4.79 per gallon<n>Frodo goes flying for the first time
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:What do customers do in a store? Choices:  A: hunt B: pay merchants with money C: mail orders D: spend money E: demand satisfaction<n>Output:		 If customers A and B spend money, then what do merchants do? Answer:  Merchant sell goods.  Cashiers help them purchase those goods.  Buyers pay cashiers with money.<n>Input:  What is the average hourly wage?<n>Output:  Find the average hourly wage for the top 1.5 percent of the US population in this month.  Then divide that figure by 100,000.  That's the average hourly wage nationwide.<n>Input:  How many workers in the United States work in restaurants and bars?<n>Output: What is the total number of workers in the United States working in restaurants and bars?  Find the percentage of this nationwide workforce where the hours of work are long - more than 50%.  Then divide that figure, by 100,000 and that is the entire nation's hourly workforce.<n>Input:  Whose home does the average hourly wage for women workers pay?<n>Output:  What is the hourly wage paid for the average hourly wage for men workers?<n>Input:  The answer to  the second question is _______<n>Output:  The answer given by ____ is 80<n>Input:  Which is bigger: the price of a gallon of gas or the cost of a meal?<n>Output:  You can find the answer to ________ by looking at the following graph:<n>Input: The answer to the second question is_____<n>Output:  The total cost of a gallon of gas is ______<n>Input:  The average hourly wage is ______<n>Output:  $40<n>Input: $5 = ______<n>Output:  The average salary of computer programmers is $ ____<n>Input:  The cost of lunch for the average hourly wage is ______ dollars<n>Output:  The cost of a meal is ______ dollars<n>Input:  The hourly wage of the average hourly wage paid by computer programmers is $ _____ dollars<n>Output:  To get the total cost of a gallon it is: ________<n>Input:  The monthly cost of a gallon of gasoline is ______ dollars per month<n>Output:  Monthly the cost of food is ______ dollars per month.  Monthly food and gas prices are always _______ _______<n>Input:  The national average hourly wage is ______.<n>Output:  The annual average hourly wage is ______ _______________<n>Input:<n>Number of hours worked in a year: _____ hours<n>Output:  Each worker works __/ __+ x weeks.  Thus __/ __+ x ____ ____ hours

The first teacher sent home instructions for the four boys to perform a talent show during recess.  The fourth and fifth boys performed in the talent show. How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:Where might someone find old clothing? Choices:  A: revealing information B: being ridiculed C: problems D: more funding E: telling all<n>Output:		 People want to know the secret of success<n>So the secret is:  A) they need more capital B) they need to raise capital to succeed C) they can't be criticized D) they need to invest time in the company E) investing in the company is the best thing they can do
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week. How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane. What kind of sandwich do you build?<n>Output: A tuna salad?<n>Input: You decide to not eat lunch at work tomorrow.<n>Output: A pizza?<n>Input: You choose not to eat at a resturant tomorrow.<n>Output: Panera?<n>Input: You go shopping and don't buy lunch tomorrow.<n>Output: Taco Bell?<n><n>In my last few posts, the topic had been some of the common business and finance questions. It seems that now it would be good to cover a personal finance topic, since many of the questions raised about business and finances are probably the same, but the way in which they are answered can vary slightly.<n>So let's look at the question "Do You Know How to Use Your Credit Cards?". It starts out as follows:<n><n>The first picture below is of your credit card statement. The second picture is of the statement after a particular transaction. (Both are shown on the left-hand side of the image). The third picture is a "look up" statement. These are statements which provide a record of how much you spent as well as your balance.<n><n>First, let's talk about what credit cards are. Credit cards are just another item on your bill card. When shopping for groceries and buying food for the family, a check or bill is a more convenient way to go. Many people prefer to pay for a bill with a credit card instead of a check. It may seem that spending money with a credit card is more cost-efficient. Not necessarily.<n><n>Credit cards also have an annual percentage rate based on what you owe. If your credit card balance is too high to go to 0%, you will have an interest rate based on the balance.

Choices:  A: fast food restaurant B: plate C: bowl D: freezer E: oven<n>Output:		 $4/meal. $15+14=$$4+14=$20<n>So there is $21 and $10 for food and fuel<n>That would be a weekly bill of $100 per week<n>So the total would be $240 for food and fuel + $40 for gas weekly<n><n>Input: What is the fastest train in the world?<n>Output:  The average speed of the train is 300 miles per hour<n>That's 7 miles per hour<n>Or, in simpler terms, the train can go 6.7 miles per hour<n>That means it can travel 6.7 miles a second<n>It can get there in only 3 seconds<n><n>Input: What's the oldest house in Canada?<n>Output:  It was built in 1870<n>That's 1,050 years old<n>That means that today is the 1,038th anniversary of the opening of the house<n>So on December 1st of every year, there are exactly 1,038 days that have been a day<n>That means today's date is December 1, 2013<n><n>Input:What's the largest city in Mexico?<n>Output:  Mexico City is the capital of Mexico, with a population of 12 million<n>That means there are 12 million people<n>That's 10,000,000 people<n>That means there is 10,000,000 more people than on this Earth in 2014<n><n>Input:What the largest airport in the world?<n>Input:  The Heathrow Airport in London, UK is the largest in the world<n>Output:  JFK is the largest because the airport was built to carry a huge number of cars, and it still carries a great many cars<n><n>Input: Who is the inventor of the transistor?<n>Output:  John von Neumann<n>Input:  The transistor was invented in 1930 by the French physiologist Émile Louis Bechdel<n>Input:  Bechdel came up with the name "transistor" in 1937, during the Nazi Occupation of France<n>Input:  The world's first transistor was used in the transistor radio by Frank R. Wilcox<n><n>Input: Which of these is a word consisting of two consecutive letters?<n>Input: The following two letters:  A and N<n>Output:  A, N, A, N<n><n>Input: Which is the word containing all of the following characters?<n>Output:  T and O<n>Input:  T, O, T, O<n>Output:  G and S<n>Output:  O, S
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:Where does a marmoset not usually go? You’re taking a shower in the shade of a tree. How did you know this? 3) Your car is stolen. What do you do next?  4) You have a party and have had a bottle of whisky. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:What prevents someone from getting sleep at night? Choices:  A: relax B: dreams C: have nightmares D: restlessness E: snore<n>Output:		  A.  Sleeping A.  Restless B. Dreams C. Have Nightmares D. Snore<n>So for the input James chose sleeping > being restless.  Therefore the final answer is sleeping > being restless.<n>So James' final answer = sleeping > being restless.

It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:She had a knack for entertaining, everybody told he she had a what? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:Where do you buy treats for kids over a counter? If you buy 1000 or more treats it is a treat.<n>So you get 1200 units per 2 treats.  If you buy 200 or more you get 1500 units per 2 treats.<n>How many treats can you buy total, assuming you buy every treat, which you buy every time you go to a store?<n>Input: What did you get when you ate 1 slice of cake? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:What place would a person go to look at zebras? Choices:  A: zoo B: museum C: hospital D: desk E: opera<n>Output:		<n>A: zoo B: hospital C: desk D: opera<n>But if you asked me to choose, I would only choose B if all were included.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:The window across the street was broken and John felt guilty. He never meant to damage what? Choices:  A: friend's house B: curtains C: space shuttle D: front door E: classroom<n>Output:		 He broke nothing (not sure)<n><n>Input: In a year, John earns a total of $1353.66 at the gym. How much is he earning at the gym?<n>Output: John earns 1353.66 * $2-20 = $<<1353.66=56>>56<n>Which brings the total to a total of $56*2=$<<56*2=144>>144<n>So he earns $144 (56/4) * $2-20 == $<<56*2=72>>72<n>Which brings the total of **72*2=$<<72*2=256>>256<n>So he earns $256 (56*2) * $2-10 = $<<56*2+20=16>>16<n>So the total is $16 (56/2) * $2-$10 = $<<56+20=12>>12<n>So the final answer $12<n><n>Input:John gets a new watch and has to keep track of all his activity.  The new watch costs $350.  So for every 10 minutes he wears the watch, can he track the minute he wears it.  What is the activity he is tracking?<n>Output:John's watch counts a minute every 4 seconds for every activity he does<n>So it counts every 4 seconds to track whether he puts on and removes the watch every 10 minutes<n>So it counts out every 4 seconds the minute he puts the watch on and every 12 seconds the minute he puts it on again<n>So it counts every 8 minutes the minute he removes it and 12 minutes the minute he puts it back on<n>So it counts out each 10 minutes the minute he puts the time on the watch<n><n>Input:At the gym the other day James met Jim Bob.  James asked him how he was doing.  Jim Bob said he was feeling good.  James said "Good!  So, Jim Bob, why aren’t you working out?"  Jim Bob says "Well, I don’t like heavy lifting."  James says "Well, why not?"  Jim Bob replies "Well, I love beer."  James says "Okay, go ahead and take the weight of one beer."  Jim Bob says "I can’t do 50 ounces!"  James says "Why not?"  Jim Bob says “It is far heavier than I can deal with!"  James says "Oh?”  Jim Bob says "You ever done squat and gone
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:I was shopping at a car dealership, what did a salesman do? Choices:  A: appear suddenly B: bottom out C: go downtown D: scream E: roll over<n>Output:		 A: appear suddenly<n>B: bottom out<n>C: go downtown<n>D: scream<n>E: roll over<n>That's the way it is in the dealership sales business<n><n>Input:Jack is given 5 tickets to a game by a friend of his.  The tickets cost $7 each.  Each ticket is sold out for a game.  Jack needs to decide if he wishes to go to the game.  He should try and see if his friend will sell his tickets to someone else.  If so, Jack should use the tickets to go to a nearby town he can go to in the offseason.  If not, he should bring the tickets to the sports bar where his friend works.  If his friend would not sell anything, he may then use the tickets to buy groceries and beer for the next night.  He should also get cashback at the grocery store to spend it in his normal life savings.  He should also keep in touch with his friend to see how other friends react.  Finally, he should then use the tickets for other activities he may be interested in.  Which one should he do?<n>Output: A: buy 10 tickets, B: get discount at the arena, C: buy tickets from sports bar, D: go to game, E: bring tickets,<n>So he should buy the tickets from the sports bar if the offer is good, B if not, D if there is a discount, C if he likes the venue, and E if he would like to go to a local restaurant.<n>So the final choice is D<n><n>Input:Jack makes 100 pizza slices, using the following dough:  Flour  Water  Vinegar  Salt  Pepper<n>Output: 100 pizzas, including 2 for each person in your house.<n>So Jack used the dough to make 100 pizzas, which is 100 * 90 = 300.  Then he used two of the pizzas for each person in his house, which is 120 pizzas, or 300 + 120 =<n><n>Input:<n>Jack got 50 dollars by going bowling for 2 hours on 1 dollar bill.  He can do it again at 50 bucks.  Why is that?<n>Output:<n>A: bowling is a dollar-a-game at most places<n>B: bowling is a dollar bill<n>C: bowling is $50<n>D: it is time for a change...<n>So it's 50% off<n><n>Input:<n>Mary bought 10 carrots, and 10 potatoes  for 10 dollars

The previous one was broken.  Her boyfriend bought it the previous year for $500.<n>Input: The problem is her boyfriend buys very expensive computers and hers are much less expensive. He bought his computer for $450.<n>Output: He bought a $1500 computer and paid $450 for his computer<n>So with no extra cost his computer now cost 2 x $450=2.5 x $450=3.75x $1000 = $1000<n>So he now pays $750<n>That means his previous computer cost $500 times 3 x $1000 = $600.<n>That means he had a total average cost of $500 x 3 = $900.<n>That means his previous year's computer was cheaper than this year's by $900<n>So the final answer for the computer is $900 x 3 = $2500<n><n>input: Bill wanted a $1000 for a job that he can do for $200. The current agent said that job is paid for $500<n>Output: He asked for $1500<n>Input: Bill wants a computer that costs $1500<n>output: Bill can get a computer (for 250$) for his age ($250 x 2)<n>Input:  Bill wants to get a new computer for $1,000<n>output:  bill can get a computer for $1,500<n>Input:  Bill is going to get a new computer with Internet for $800<n>output:  Bill can get a computer for his age ($800 x 2) for free $1200<n>Output: Bill can get a new computer for his age ($1200 x 2) now for $900<n>

Do you know what a word in the sentence means? Answer: Yes, we don't know that.2. How many times do you say:  "Is it my turn?" Answer: 4.9: "Did it work?" Answer: 8.9: "Is it an excuse?" Answer: 4.20: "Where's the problem?" Answer: 3.5: "Did it work?" Answer: 14.5: "That won't work." Answer: 12.5: "Is it an explanation?" Answer: 11.5: "What did we do wrong?" Answer: 10.5.

How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:Mark wanted to know the truth, because he didn't want to continue existing in what? Choices:  A: understand B: were there C: ignorance D: in-between E: ignorant<n>Output:		 His only choices were A: Understand B: were there C; D: In-between<n>So he chose D<n><n>Input:Adam needed some food for lunch but found it hard to eat as a vegetarian. He had been a vegetarian for so long that he forgot how different eating meat was. Why was eating meat so different from eating a vegetable? Answer.<n>Outlook: "vegetarian" = "vegan vegan."  So he was a vegetarian= <Vegetarian<n>He was vegan=<Vegan><n><n>Input:What is the difference between a "Coke" and a "Fanta"? Answer: A: Coke has caffeine and is soft drink. Fanta has no caffeine and is "hard" drinks.  B: Coke has maltodextrin and is a carbonated drink. Fanta has maltodextrin, but not caffeine. Both are soft drinks but don't have the same ingredients.  C: Coke contains caramel color and is carbonated water. Fanta contains caramel color, but does not have carbonation. Both are soft drinks<n>Coke is soda ~~ soda ~~ soda  Coca-cola ~~ Pepsi ~~ Tab ~~ Snapple ~~ Slurpee ~~ Slurpee<n>Fanta is soft drink ~~ soda ~~ soft drink  Fanta ~~ Slurpee
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:Where is disease often spread but shouldn't be? The probability is 1/24. How do I calculate the total yield to get the return in the table?<n>Output:<n>So how long did it take to sell the bond (36 months)?<n>Then how much did you get at maturity (6% interest)?<n>So the yield of 6% divided by 36 is 10<n>So you get: 10%/(6+36)*36=5.53<n>And so the return on the bond is 5.53/36 = 1.5 %<n><n>Here is an example that uses some of the techniques that you saw above:<n><n>Input: X is a 1.5x return on a bond with 10% and a maturity of 84 months. The yield is 2/4. How do I derive the distribution of the bond?<n>Output:<n>The yield of 2% divided by 84 is 4<n>So the net income from this bond is 48%<n>So the bond's return is 8%/84=4.4 / 3 or 5.9%<n>And so the bond's return on average over time is 4%.<n>So the average yield is 5.9% (over the course of the entire investment)<n>So the average income distribution is 2/3.33/12 = 0.97<n>And the median is 0.97<n>So the median is roughly 1% / 36 = 1.3<n>So if the median is lower than 0.97 that would be extremely unlikely (I assume this because the median is higher than 0.97 and lower than 1.3).<n>Input: A price of X is $200. You know how much money it takes to pay it off in 20 years. How much will you get?<n>Output:<n>Assuming the bonds will pay dividends at the same rate as it takes to pay it them off,
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:A person notices popcorn, cotton candy on the grass, where is he likely? E-    State park or State forest<n>So the final answer would be:  (A= A.)<n><n>Input:A company has 10 employees and is using three computers per worker to process his orders. The management needs to hire less employees for the maintenance staff, and they may not get the needed work because they are spending much more money on computers which requires more technology to operate.  (This would increase the maintenance staff's budget, so you would need to consider the pay.)<n>Output:The maintenance staff is running a 24 hour service which is more efficient on a $$$$ scale<n><n>Input: John has three children and he decided to increase the number of children living with him. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input:What corner areas have lots of windows? So if you press Tab then enter and hit the enter key, then tab again it will add two lines to each side of that block of text.  The resulting blocks of text will then be filled with the same paragraph text as the preceding one.  A normal excel block of text is 552 lines long so if you can fit two lines of text into a block of text of 552 lines then, using the formula, it will take 4.6 times as long to paste the second line.  Using this formula, to paste the second line add another 562 lines to

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane. How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane. If he succeeds with one, he will feel better.<n>Input:A person decides to play a game.  If they succeed in that, they will be happy to play the game.  If they fail at that, they will feel dissatisfied.  If they fail to look good, then they will be dissatisfied if their looks fail them.
